text: Piwo skonsumowane. Ocena na podstawie retrospekcji w celu uzupełnienia profilu.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017  Rami Rami is drinking an Anchor Bock Beer by Anchor Brewing Company at Konstruktorska Business CenterNiby wszystko na miejscu, melanoidynowe ewidentnie, opiekanie jest, ale z kolei to ciala nie ma i troche alko wylazi z wszak niewielu %... Rami Rami: I to to alko takie troche rozpuszczalnikowe w sumie :( Ocena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).
Aroma and flavor are very very good.In general, It is a good beer. I like it a lot.

Bottle. Dark brown with beige small head and some marks or lacing. Aromas of dark fruits and caramel, rather medium but very pleasant. Medium to heavy body, malty, roasted, caramel taste with right sweetness. Im not a big fan of bocks, this one was really good.

12 oz bottle shared by ebone1988. The pour is a dark brown with a thin cap of light tan head and a couple spots of lace. The aroma is pretty chocolatey. There is a nice dry roasted malt and a pretty heavy metallic tendency. There isn't a lot of other notable things going on. The flavor is surprising. There is a good chocolate and a nice malt profile. The metallic is there a little bit, but it's not as prominent as the nose. There is a dry roast that pops up about half way through. The mouth feel is decently creamy with a soft velvety carbonation and a lingeringly chocolatey aftertaste. I actually think I like the aftertaste better than the actual taste, but it's good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is metallic, light, light malt, nutty, light chocolate. Appearance is brown, light tan head. Taste is roasted malt, nutty, deep burned flavor, decent. Mouthfeel is medium body, medium carbonation. Overall, this isn?t too bad, and it got me the Style King badge, and is also the 1000th rating of this beer.

Bottle.

A- Dark fruits, subtle caramel.

A- Black color, black liquid, beige head.

T- Dark fruits, caramel, molasses.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, complex finish.

O- A great intro into this style. Lots of dark fruits and sugars going on and smooth as can be. Loved it.
Bottle in Amsterdam. Dark red body with medium head. Nose of malts, caramel and fruits. Taste is the same and toasty. A good bock. Well balanced.

Anchor Bock is one of those brews thats eluded me for a long time. Well, no longer. Bock was tonights pizza beer. Rich, German-style beer and salty, cheesy pizza is a combination I love. Anchor Bock was perfect for the fare. It poured brown with off-white bubbles up top. Aroma was full, rich, and fruity. Flavor had lots of devilishly tasty malty stuff. Chocolate, molasses, dark fruit, and caramel. The barley and wheat created a lot of sweetness, yet this beer managed to not be cloying. While its a big beer, Bock was balanced and smooth. Anchor, its been too long since weve done something new together. Lets get together again soon, yes?
Bottle. No detailed notes on this one - aroma and flavor both strongly reminiscent of chocolate-covered raisins. Small hop bite at the end. Not my thing.
Coloração escura. Aroma suave mas marcante. Colar denso de pouca duração. Leve amargor. Retrogosto tostado, de café. Corpo leve. Excelente!

Casi negra, opaca. Buen aroma, caramelo, malta y lupulos. En boca, sorpende por la combinación de los tonos aromaticos florales y frutales de las ales de la marca junto con amargores secos de café tipo stouts. Cremosa y sorprendente.
Mega intensywny, karmelowo-chlebowy aromat. W sensie piwo pachnie chlebem, kupionym dzien wczesniej w piekarni. Niezle.Dosc slodkie, karmelowe. Przyjemna interpretacja kozlaka.
Cor marrom escura, brilhante. Espuma boa, bege e persistente. No aroma caramelo, chocolate e tostado. Paladar frutas secas e grãos torrados. Retrogosto seco e levemente amargo.

Bottle. Dark amber, red in colour with white head. In aroma caramel and malt with a hint of dried fruit. In taste caramel and toasted malt mainly. Surprisingly low bodied, medium bitter. Doesnt really taste like a proper bock, isnt that bet on the other hand.
Cerveja de bela cor marrom brilhante. Aromas de caramelo e pouco frutada. Sabor doce de malte com pouquíssimo amargor de lúpulo. Corpo leve. Boa.
Pours a very dark deep ruby with medium tan head. Aroma of sweet malt, dark fruit and hops. Tastes of chocolately and fruity with some caramel malt and a light bitter finish. Light to medium bodied.

Not bad, but too sweet for my taste. It pours a warm brown color with a lot of head. The aroma is sweet malt. Its very sweet smelling, and the flavor is even sweeter. A little spice, some nutmeg, some ginger, some fig... but mostly, a butter-sugar-molasses thing going on in the flavor. This wasnt bad but I wont have it again.
bottle. Brown with one finger head. Malty with some caramel and toffee flavors. Balance of sweet notes initially with a hoppy bitterness in the finish.
Dark brown colour. Aroma of roasted malts. The same is the taste. Slighty watery aftertaste. For dunkler bock it should have nearly 2% higher abv.

Bottled. Pour into snifter, black porter color, big tan head. Aroma is toffee, fig, cherry, plum, caramel, slight burnt sugar. Like a malt forward Barleywine. Really awesome Aroma. Flavor is sweet candied sugar. Really really sweet sugar. Cherries, plums, dark fruits, caramel. Very sweet but not unpleasant. But the body is a bit too effervescent. Otherwise really good.

12oz bottle from Masuyos Liquor in Asagaya. Poured into a shaker pint. Dark brown color with a modest tan head. Roasted coffee, toffee, chocolate and malt aromas present. Slightly bitter resiny taste surrounded by nice toasted malts. Rich and dry finish.

American Bock, and the land of the free! In my humble opinion, go for Doppelbock instead, too soft for my taste!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours clear dark mahogany with some beige foam. Aroma is soft, caramelly and malty. Not much hop presence. Taste is slightly bittersweet at first, then longer caramel and roast bitterness remains on the tongue. Quite pleasant actually. Body is medium-full, feels stronger than it really is - which is definitely a perk. Good one.

Rating #1105 - May 25, 2014 - Taste of Spruce Grove. Sample. Dark brown pour with a tan head that fades fairly slowly. Mild-medium carbonation. Aroma is coffee, hint of toffee and roasted malt. Taste is roasted malt sweetness leading to a dry, yet balanced finish. Malty sweetness lingers on the pallet leaving you yearning for the end of the bottle. Anchor beer has a little bit of a spruce hit for me in almost all of their malt-forward efforts. Im not sure that its off-putting however.

April 10th, 2013 - Picked up a six pack of these during a Trader Joes run, and have been slowly making my way through them since. Theyre a fine end of day refresher, but just barely the kind of beer I can treat myself to at the end of a hard day. The body is dark, or too dark to catch any light through, and the head is a cork-like thick body of foam. Once this dies down, the aroma the Anchor Bock gives off is fresh malt, like the smell of a brewery on kilning day, and grainy, but not much more is detectable. The flavor is defined by the body, which is heavily carbonated, though the mid-taste brings some clarity and a dry, milk chocolate edge, and a curious chèvre tanginess. It gets drier as it goes, and the flavors crash a little bit, with the tang being the schoolyard bully, and getting along poorly with the grain-bladed flavors and touches of roasted nuts.

From a 0.355l bottle @ De Wildeman. This is a deep and dark, cola colored one clear as so and it has a really good looking almost a little fluffy dark beige head. Like the aroma here. Slightly burnt sugary, actually a little bit like coke. Hints of spices also. Nutmeg, rye bread and licorice, watered down licorice? A soft roasted touch also. Like it. A fair amount of flavor also. Feels light oily in the mouth and it soft and gentle on the carbonation. Caramelly darkness, a roasted hints. Theres also some licorice here. Old coffee and its leaving a slightly mouth drying tail. I like it in a bocky way. 25.09.2014

25.09.2014, 0,35l bottle @ In de Wildeman:
Nice light brown creamy longlasting head. Aroma is slightly sour-ish dry, weeds, sour coffee, licorice, grass, heather, herbs, dark malts, dark sugar. Taste is slightly dry and harsh, weeds, sour coffee, harsh yeast, heather, paper, almond essence, bark, grass, licorice. Medium to longlasting bitterness, harsh slightly watery mouthfeel. Fair enough.

Couleur noire, légère mousse beige. Super nez malté, chocolat noir, note de fruits noirs et caramel. Gout fort malté suivi dun puissant chocolat noir, qui depose un malt cacao un peu amer sur la langue. Corps leger et bien balancé, rond en bouche. Notes de caramel et fruits noirs en fin de bouche, bien longue. Très belle surprise!
Très intense a seulement 5.5%, nickel Anchor! 
Merci a la Bièrerie à illkirch davoir autant dAnchor à proposer.
Bottle. Clear dark brown color, tan head. Aroma of toffee, caramel. Taste is chocolate, caramel, licorice. Decent.
Bruine, bijna zwarte kleur met een goede kraag. Ruikt zoetig, drop, salmiak, chocolade. Smaakt drop, salmiak, zoethout. Prettig zoet.
"very smooth, medium bodied solid effort from Anchor. Rich and flavorful as the brewer describes. slightly nutty, slightly hoppy, bigger on the malt, but pretty well balanced. recommended."

355ml bottle at home. Pours dark with red highlights. Good lasting tan foam head. Good lacing on the way down. Honey, cherry, wood, Berry marzipan aroma. Flavour is cherry, roast malt, brown sugar yeast, bread. Very dry on the finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Light body, low carbonation.

12 oz bottle @ home (probably the very last batch). Very dark brown color, clear. Rocky light beige head. Aromas: red fruit, candies, a bit artificial actually. Red fruit and sweet malts retronasal. Flavor is light to moderate sweet, roasted, slightly droppig/licorice. Body is quite thin. Finishes slightly dry, somewhat roasted, a bit droppig, light bitter. Didnt like the aroma, but the rest was OK. Not a bock though.
12 oz bottle pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of sweet malts, caramel and toffee. Taste is malts and fruit.
Aromas of caramel, toast, and subtle spice like cream soda. Deep brown with a lasting off-white head. Some sweetness, malt forward. Medium bodied.
Aroma of dark malt, caramel, dark fruit, light molasses. Flavour is malty, caramel, medium sweet, with a light bitter finish. Nice Bock.

Bottle @ weekly tasting shared by Dutchdrebus. Nice dark brown color with a dark red glare coming through when held into the light, average sized beige head. Aroma is malts, sugar, sweetness, a hint of candy, molasses. Taste malts, light to moderately sweet, a hint of wood somehow, lightly raisins. Suitable body, average carbonation. Not bad at all.

Very dark ruby colour, beige head. Aroma of caramel, mollasses, dark fruits, bread. Taste is light to medium sweet, almost no bitterness, very well balanced. Medium body, slick texture, soft carbonation.

Bottle, 355ml, poured into a snifter at home, ABV 5.5%
Dark brown colour on the body with nice ruby shades when hold against the light but then again just some hints of it because its so dark. Two fingers of a brown thick head, creamy, with good retention, leaving medium lacing on the glass.
Aroma of roasted malts, vanilla, dark ripe fruits, some red wine-like notes.
Taste also of roasted malts, red wine, some chocolate, light alcohol although its just a 5.5% beer, lots of dark and red fruits, mildly sweet, light caramel too.
Medium body, good carbonation, smooth on the palate,as well as dry.
Very good bock, if one third of all the different bocks produced here in the Netherlands every autumn could be as good as this, we would be looking forward to the winter months.
Bottle @benzai. Amber brown color with a beige head. Smells sweet, fruity, wijnbal. Tastes sweet, roasted malts, fruity.

Bottle @ benzai. Dark amber to brown colour with a small to medium off-white to beige head. Smells sweet, some roze kermis zoetstok/wijnbal, hint of cinnamon, brown sugar. Tastes sweetish, slightly roasty, hint of coffee, hint of banana, slightly wijnbal. Decent. Medium body, nice carbo.

Dark coppery brown, tan head. Aroma of toast, cereal, nuts, and slight citrus. Taste is sweet, with caramel, toasted oats. Finishes bitter with a slight hint of citrus. Full bodied and average carbonation. Very well balanced and drinkable beer.

Pours a clear dark brown, with tan head. Aroma of rich malts. Taste is deep and a little sweet. Notes of caramel, malt, and smoke. This a delicious bock beer, smooth and very drinkable. Thumbs way up!

35.5cl bottle @ home from De Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Deep ruby-brown color, medium brownish creamy mostly lasting good lacing head. Aroma red wine, caramel, chocolate, light coffee, medium roasted malt. Taste medium sweetness, medium bitterness, light sourness. Medium to full body, slightly sticky texture, soft carbonation, caramellish bittersweet finish. Not very easy but delicious dessert beer.

Interesting Californian seasonal, one of the younger beers in the Anchor range and one of the few American bocks Ive had so far. Tanned, regularly shaped, dense and stable foam, very dark brown, clear colour with a copper-reddish hue. Herbally sweet aroma, the kind that makes me melt, with impressions of cacao powder, milk chocolate, freshly ground coffee beans, cinnamon, ginger, caramel, banana, liquorice, raisins and citrussy American hops. Taste begins caramelly and chocolatey, very malty, soft and sweetish with a slight sourish impression from the wheat malt, then quickly becoming assertively bitter with lots of mouth-filling, coffee-like toastedness as well as fresh, green, citrussy and spicy hops, long. The typically American hoppiness made it more stout-like than truly bock-like, I think, but being true to style becomes less important in a great beer like this, at least to my taste.

BOTTLE 355ML.

Look: clear ruby-brown almost black, beige frothy to creamy head.
Aroma: rich caramel, molasses, dark honey, sweet chocolate topping, some hop accents too. 
Taste: quite complex and developing flavour, starts with some burnt sugar sweetness, roast accents, salty notes, light spicy hop bitterness in the finish.
Deep brown pour with tan head and great lacing. Aroma has charred malts, maple. Medium bodied, great mouthfeel. Toasted malts, molasses, slight tartness or earthy, herbal quality. Nice.
Bottle 355 ml form Za Popent, Ljubljana. Pours dark brown with small tan head. Sweetish, ripe fruits, caramel, some chocolate. Expected a bit more.
Clear golden with lasting head and good lacing. Aroma of wheat, pine, citrus and alcohol. Flavor of wheat and cittus. Light and fizzy palate.
Dark brown, aroma of bread, caramel and a similar taste; a reasonable bock; this came after a couple of other wildly different beers so I suspect Id have enjoyed it more as a stand alone drink.

355ml bottle, pours dark brown, almost black with a small but creamy tan head. Aroma is rich chocolate malt, caramel, mince pie & cream, pistachio. Rich and creamy palate. Finish is balanced and pleasantly bitter. Very nice.

Negra, con espuma de burbuja fina que tiende a desaparecer aunque deja rastro.
Aroma a malta torrefacta y algo de hierba.
No mucho cuerpo, pero a la vez cremosa y con gasificación media.
Entra dulce, con algo de regaliz y malta quemada, pasando luego a cierta acidez. 
Refrescante y de trago largo.
a mass produced bock beer is not a bad thing; this one isnt particularly exciting, but its decent all the same.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2014 355ml bottle
Appearance: Dark brown mahogany with a 1,5 finger sized tanned creamy head. 
Aroma: Licorice, Caramel, some toasted malts and light mashmallows and a hint of dark fruit.
Taste: medium sweet, starting with caramel with light cherrie notes wit a very little bit of sourness before the bitter, Laurus nobilis licorice finish kicks in. With a licorice, coffee in the aftertaste . (Quite complex taste palate not easy to put your finger on.)

Slightly below medium body, average carbonation.


Quite unussual to bring a dark bock beer in spring, here at the other side of the pond this would probably sold as a autumn bock beer, and this one comes close to the better ones.

355ml bottle from Appellation Wines. Pours clear chestnut Britten, rocky off-white head. Aromas of creme-caramel, dark sugar, light fruitiness. Taste is sweet. Creamy texture. Sweet, spicy finish. Good.

Bottle at home shared with Sarah from Bottle:Shop St Albans. Nice chesnut brown clear pour with a lasting creamy cream coloured head. Head fades. Aroma is sweet toffee, marshmallow, unrefined sugars and candied fruits. Flavour is somewhat thin with wood, toffee, brown sugar, mineral. Some lager yeast character. Finish has some lingering burnt toffee, bandy snap thing going on. Palate is light and watery and sem-sweet.

From 0.355l bottle. Pours dark brown mahogany liquid, small tan creamy head. Aroma: Mostly fruity, sweet, resin, cherry, licorice, light espresso, bubblegum. Interesting. Taste: medium sweet, light to medium bitter, light sour. Fruity, cherry, dark chocolate, licorice, nice. Palate: medium body, oily texture, average carbonation, long bitter-sweet fruity finish. Overall: very nice bock, lot of fruits, complex body. Memorable. Enjoyed.

12oz bottle into an English pint. Pour is a deep mahogany with a small tan headd. Nose is overwhelming with rich fruit and caramel malts, though the flavour is a bit sweeter than Id hoped. Medium-full body, creamy texture, finishing dry. Very good!

On tap at Barley Brothers, Winnipeg. Dark brown pour with a ruby hue and a creamy head. Nice malty bock aroma, some dark and dried fruit notes with a touch of hops. Flavour is malty liquorice and raisin, caramel, and a nice bitter hoppy backbone. Some similar notes here to Anchor's Brekle's Brown. Quite a nice bock.

355ml bottle from Appellation Wines. 
Appearance - opaque black with a lovely fawn head. 
Nose - cake mixture with gentle sweet spices. 
Taste - chocolate and toffee. Coffee creamy background. 
Palate - medium to full bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish. 
Overall - good example of a bock.
Bottle from Rehills Newcastle. Fruity, flavoursome beer. Nice refreshing dark beer. Very enjoyable.
Dark red/brown with a tan brown head. Ripe Cherry aroma. Fruity flavour balanced by some hop bitterness. Refreshing.
(tap) deep brown with tan head - looks like a porter. Aroma is malt, but not as sweet as Id expect. Flavor is slightly toasted malt. Mouthfeel is a bit thin. I was disappointed.

The body looks like tincture of iodine with a beige head. Aroma of malts, cloves and red fruit. Taste medium bitter and light sweetness. Slightly oily mouthfeel. Not especially long but very good as all Anchor beers seem to be.

Pours deep brown in color with burgundy highlights. Large off-white head that is creamy. Aroma of dark crusty bread, molasses, and a nice hop blend. Rich and flavorful. Soft carbonation, medium body, long finish. Maybe its the scarcity of bock beers but this is delicious!
Pours a cream coloured head. Chocolate, malty, sweet nose. Hint of coffee. Nice hop flavour to this. Enjoyed it.
Bottle - big thick creamy head, very dark brown color, sweet and nutty malt aroma and flavor, mild hop profile - very good for this style, cant ever go wrong with an Anchor!

Bottle.
Appearance: The body is very dark when not seen through light, but put into view with a light source behind it the body glows a vibrant garnet hue, truly a beautiful color. The head towers over the body, at tall as the body is deep with excellent head retention and a tan hue. Stellar appearance
Aroma: The aroma leans sweet and malty with a nutty edge to it and a fruitiness, like a baby Troegenator. The fruitiness reminds me of raspberries.
Taste: Very well done bock here. The sweetness is kept in check by a hint of hop bitterness and a prominent raspberry fruitiness, but not a pungent raspberry flavor sort of watered down. A hint of caramel sweetness lingers with a slight burnt edge to it.
Palate: Moderately dense body with mild to moderate carbonation.
Overall: This is something that I would buy a lot if it were available for a cheaper price. $10.99 doesnt make me want to run and grab it for a six pack though. This is very nicely done though, a really good example of a bock.
12 ounce bottle. Rich brown color. Caramel. Toffee. But a nice follow throughout with sweetness. Pretty nice.
Tap from Lazy Dog. Pours a transparent amber with a layer of cream colored head. Aroma is sweet, slightly fruity. Taste is malty with a floral sweetness to it.
Bottle from Trader Joe's. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Molasses and chocolate on the nose, with sweet, malty flavor and some dark fruits. Surprisingly good.

From 12 ounce bottle purchased at One Stop Liquors in Bellevue, Kentucky, tasted on March 27, 2014. Dark brown/ruby hue, good toasted malt nose, sweet malty flavor with some complexity--also with chocolate, dark fruits and some bitterness to balance things out. A little chemical taste holds things back somewhat but still a fine seasonal. I hope Anchors decision to discontinue this beer after this year is reversed.

Mahogany colour with mocha head, lots of lace. Molasses and chocolate malt aroma. Creamy and tongue tingle. Molasses and roast coffee after taste with coffee oil slickness. Bitter sweet. Medium-full mouth feel. It all works together, and would have again.

Almost completely dark. Thick head with thin bubbles on pour. Head lingers longer than other bocks. Stronger hops flavor than expected, but not unpleasant. Malts are very savory. Bread or chocolate cake.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a big bread note with a touch of sweetness and a bit of toffee as well. Flavor has more of a dark bread note with a hint of light roast and a touch of sweetness in the finish.

Pours a caramel brown color with a khaki head. caramel, malt,toffee and bread aroma. Malt, caramel, toffee, toast, bread and slight chocolate flavors. Medium full body wild moderate carbonation. Slightly sweet taste with a toffee and toast finish.
For an American version of a Germanic Bock beer, this one does the trick well.

12oz bottle picked up at the COOP today.. Pours with a flimsy tannish head atop a dark brown but reveals deep clear ruby when held to a light.

Expected strong maltiness.. some toasty notes.. nothing stellar.. but pretty standard none the less.

Flavor is a little better than the nose.. more melanoidin than toasty this time around.. bitterness is just enough to balance the malts.. body is medium with medium/low carbonation.. a little bit of drying cocoa emerges as it warms.. still very clean in both the nose and palate.

Nice Bock for sure... a bit chewy, but there is a bunch of stuff going on.

Looks just like a stout: pitch black with a tan head. Aroma is fruity and seems to have a strong yeast profile.Really pleased with how this tastes, roasty malts, chocolate, fruit and just a little sweetness to balance it out. Finishes dry with a lingering finish and just a little whiff of charred dark malts.
Deep brown in colour. Aroma of dough, some light fruitiness. Mild flavour, some chocolate, fruit, slightly herbal. Nice and easy drinking beer.
Dark malts, toast, dark bread, lots of cola, a little chocolate and molasses, thin on the tongue, a little sweetness and dark fruit and a hoppy finish.
Nice and quite strong. Dark in features and nice thick strong taste. VEry enjoyable and malty.
very tasty beer...tons of flavor....i will re rate later...had a few tonight...this is a keep stocked in the fridge kinda beer.

This doesnt really fit into any traditional bock category due to its lower ABV however this is a great full flavoured lager. Pours a clear dark brown with reddish hues and a nice frothy brown head that leaves lots of lacing. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, plums, raisins and light molasses. Flavour is plums, dates, earth hops, light bitterness, grainy. Mouthfeel is nice and dry after a lot of sweetness in the aroma and initially up front. This really is a great beer and is closest to a doppelbock, however it just doesnt have enough body. If the body was a little fuller to the point that some alcohol was nicely shining through this could easily be a 50 point beer.

355ml bottle. Surprising dark colour, tar-like, until you hold it up to the light then it looks like deep red blood. Moderate milk chocolate head. Aroma is figs, dates and herbal hops. Slight chocolate. Taste was roasted coffee, chocolate and malt. Light body, slightly oily like wine. Overall, full aroma and taste, great spring bock.

From a bottle into a pint glass. Pours a gorgeous purple brown with a scant light brown head. Aroma is also great and berriful with deep wood. And that's where things end. Mouthfeel is fizzy and weird. Taste is watery with a ton of minerals and ink. Ech. Pretty bad. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
(bottle) clear dark reddish amber colour with a small brown head; aroma of stewed fruit; thin palate; balanced flavour
Chocolate malt aroma. Dark amber in color with one finger head. Lite malt taste and bitterness. Good session beer.

Bottle, many thanks to StefanSD. Láhev 355 ml. Aroma je velmi příjemné, sladce sladové s karamelovým nádechem a ovocnými podtóny. Pěna je světle hnědá, jemná, vysoká a drící. Barva samotného piva je temně rubínová. Chuť je výrazná, sladího rázu s výrazným nádechem ostruin a kanadských borůvek, fini je slabě ovocně nahořkly a drící. V ústech pivo působí poměrně lehce a zakulaceně, má střední říz. Celkově se jedná o velmi zajímavé pivo, výrazného aroma, příjemné chuti a dobré pitelnosti.
An overly sweet and rather uninspired typical american styles bock. Not a fan at all.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2014 Appearance: very dark brown color around the edges when held up to the light, mostly just black otherwise, pours with a small tan head that dissipates quickly

Aroma: malty sweetness, syrup, molasses, 

Taste: sweet, darker malt flavor, almost coffee like, some grain comes thru, leaves a slightly bitter aftertaste

Palate: leaves mouth dry, leaves bitter aftertaste, average carbonation, average mouthfeel, not too heavy and not too light

Overall: not a bad beer, almost like a watered down stout, Id drink it again

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 17, 2014 12 oz bottle poured into a snifter. First aromas off the pour are grass, cookie dough, candy sugar, a light note of berries, and a mild chocolate and vanilla combination. As it settles, some notes of caramel show up and the berries turn more towards raisin and fleshy fruit. A light coffee note comes in towards the end of the drink The pour is a rich dark, caramel-cola color with a large, puffy brown head that has a muffin-like look to it. It slowly reduces down to a messy, but abundant, frothy, lumpy head that leaves an above average amount of splotchy lacing. A medium malty sweetness is matched by a more full, but mellow, light bitter, with a background sourness in very trace amounts (sour grapes came to mind). The beer has medium-light body, with a thin, somewhat creamy texture and a decent amount of very soft, pillowy carbonation. The mouthfeel starts out with a rich chocolate milk flavor, then turns to a  strong, but mellow spruce-like bitterness that fades by the the middle of the sip, and more sweet chocolate malt / malted milk ball and a light sour grape flavor swells in to take its place. Theres also a seltzer-esque mutedness to the drink. A mellow bitter dryness shows up at the finish in the form of resin-y coffee grounds with dark chocolate and is complimented by a milky sweet berries and cream and vanilla bean flavor. The aftertaste is over-toasted bread (not quite burnt, but close) in moderate strength and length.

To celebrate my 1200th rating on ratebeer I decided to have Anchors now retired Anchor Bock(replaced by an IPA). 2013 bottle so one year old from Sugaya & served in a snifter, it pours a dark reddish-brown that becomes a deep black in the glass with a thin brown head which dissipates fairly fast but leaves nice lacing. Lovely ripe plum, figs & port notes very fruity with dark malts. Medium bodied with a silky mouthfeel. The flavor is fruity cherry & berries, quite sweet with caramel & roasty malts in the finish. A delicious beer that makes me think of fruits dipped in chocolate or caramel. Too bad it is being discontinued but I can see how this beer isnt a "trendy" style in the US.

355ml. Bottle. 
Pours dark brown with tan head. 
Aroma caramel, sweet, dark fruits, sugar, molasses, malts. 
Taste sweet, fresh. 
Mouthfeel thin, bit creamy. 
Nice brew!
This one poured a lighter brown with a beige head. Aroma was nutty and caramel. Flavor was similar, with grassy notes. Smooth and unflawed but boring.

Bottle 0,355L. Very dark brown colour with big, creamy, light brown head. I would expect strong malty aroma at bock style of beer, but strong hoppy aroma with grass and orange dominates here. Of course there is malty strong coffee and chocolate aroma, but somwhere way back in the background. Taste starts light acidic and become heavy bitter with long lasting aftertaste. Full bodied, oily texture and lively carbonation.

Bottles sampled 2010 and onwards, as recently as 2012Quite light in color, a deep amber with darker mahogany tints. Clear with a beige head that is small and recedes quickly to cover.Sweet caramel and biscuity malt notes in the nose are quite clean and straightforward, with a touch of herbal/spicy hops lending a bit of dryness. Light vanilla, cream, honey and melanoidin malt notes emerge as it warms and I dont find any DMS or other flaws. Alcohol is well-concealed, aroma strength is medium.Rich and malty, though not overly sweet or underattenuated, the maltiness takes on a slightly grainy or washed-out character as it warms and the beer breathes, in part due to the filtration, Im sure, but perhaps due to the attenuation. Some molasses-like sweetness is left on the finish along with some slightly bitter herbal hop notes. The malt flavor is pretty spot-on for the style though, any other shortcomings aside. Biscuits, melanoidins, caramel, light vinousness; its all here. Perhaps a touch too astringent after its warmed fully, with a dull sort of brown sugar-like sweetness sitting on the finish. Best drunk well-chilled. Too bad they filter it, but alas. Body is medium, with the carbonation peppery as in most of their beers.

Aroma: Toffe, café, caramelo, malta de chocolate, lúpulo, flores, frutos negros (ciruelas, pasas,...)

Entrada en boca/amargor: Es dulce, el amargor cae a mitad del paladar. Acidez equilibrada, tiene cuerpo.

Sabor: Malta tostada, torrefactos (café, chocolate,..), regaliz, caramelo, frutos negros, tofee,...

Anotaciones: Utiliza malta barley y wheat.

Pours a dark mahogany with a thick head of tan foam. Nose is of malt and molasses. Nice and creamy on the palate, the taste is full of malt, wheat, dark molasses and flavorful hops. A full bodied brew that is a fine complement to brats, burgers or deli sandwiches.

Appears faintly murky in a deep russet body with a latte coloured head. Aromas of currants, allspice, raisins, plums and dates, Christmas cake and rich, sweet amintillado sherry. The aromas are complex and demand attention. There is a full sherrylike flavour along with plenty of carbonation. The above flavours form a riot of deeply complex tastes. The enduring flavour is that of ripe apple peelings and is not nearly as rich as I would have expected. Not that Im disappointed at all. Just not at all what I was expecting.

355 ml bottle. BB 12/2012. From bierzwerg.de.
Dark brown colour with average to big creamy tan head.
Sweet roasted malty aroma with berries and hops. 
Flavour is strong roasted malt, some sweetness, hops and dark chocolate. 
Roasted and dark for a Bock. Smooth.

Pours very dark brown with a thick frothy brown head. Aroma is sweet malt, caramel and toffee with hints of roastiness. Taste is also sweet malt, caramel and light roasty notes leading to a sweet lightly hoppy finish. Pretty true to the style and quite enjoyable.

Malty molasses aromas come off what appears to be black but is really brownish red body with a medium tan head.  Those aromas follow right into the taste with some dark chocolate and a good dose of hop bitterness which is earthy and "dry leaf" in nature.  The body has some creaminess to it, but is not thick; the dryness of the flavor makes it seem rather thin.  Leaves behind a bit of that chocolate and alcohol, but is quite clean for such a dark beer.   Not terribly exciting or complex, but a well made beer that is true to style.
Un goût vineux léger, une bière pas mauvaise. Une couleur assez foncée. Une petite mousse agréable.

12 oz bottle. It pours a clear dark ruby colour with a billowing frothy brown head. heavy aroma of dark fruit, sweet spices and brown sugar, light milk chocolate and liquorice. flavour is mostly the same, with a dry roasted-maltiness coming through in the finish, accompanied by burnt toast and a hint of mushrooms. body is watery, with average carbonation.

Bottle. Moderate roasted and caramel for the malt, light to moderate cooked orange for the hops, light dough for the yeast with toffee and steak sauce in thebackground. Head is small to average size, frothy, beige with no lacing and is almost fully diminishing. Color is hazy mahogany. Flavor starts faintly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly to moderately acidci and moderaely to heavily bitter. Palate is medium, watery with a lively to fizzy carbonation and a tart tingly finish. This is a tasty and rich beer, but it seems a little lacking in sweetness and too bitter as a Dunkler Bock.

8/29/12. 12oz bottle from Grassroots. Deep amber pour with a small tan head that cuts in half, lasts a bit, and laces okay. Slightly sour aroma with lots of bread and toast as well as bits of caramel and roast. More bitter flavor, though that tartness hits again, with more caramel, some charcoal and ash, and a dose of dark fruits and brown sugar. Interesting. Not as great as I was hoping.

355ml bottle (White Horse, Parsons Green)
Rich malty aroma, good toastiness, some yeast. Some dark caramel. Very deep red, tight head. Slightly watery, quite fizzy. Mostly treacly - thats most of the taste, and all of the finish. Definitely had far better bocks from Germany.
Pours dark red/brown with a lot of thick tan head. Aroma caramel, chocolate, bread, and herbs. Taste is roasty and chocolaty.

Bottle from wegmans. Pours dark brown with a small white head that dissipates rapidly. Aroma is full of dark bread. It reminds me of marble rye and pumpernickel bread. There is also some light alcohol and malt sweetness in there.taste is very malty and had some chocolate sweetness. Good palate.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours dark brown with a decent tan head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, dark fruit, and chocolate.  Taste is malt, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit, and some hops.  Quite enjoyable.
Bottle, pours a dark brown, aroma is soy and flavour is soy, it was just soy all over, it was not enjoyable for me. I do believe the beer may have been old.
Pours a dark mahogany with medium tan head, decent lacing.  Aroma of almost roasted malt, chocolate, slight berad, caramel, and herbal hops.  Flavor matches well and makes for an enjoyable brew.
Taste is spice, caramel, brown sugar and malt.  Very smooth finish.  Nice beer.
Cerveja com pouca formação de espuma, bastante aromática , pesada, baste corpo. Sente-se um amargor e uma sensação residual um pouco doce.

Pours dark ruby-mahogany with a finger of brown head. Smells spicy with some solid malt sweetness. Taste hints of roast, lots of chocolate, caramel, and some spicy hops. Medium-bodied with a slick, wet texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Anchor Bock Beer finishes with some chocolate-like sweetness.

Bottle from Ninas. Pours a dark amber brown colour with a fair light tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, candy sugar, toffee and alcohol. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and CO2 prickle and an oily mouth-feel. Fairly bitter. Not bad with fairly prominent alcohol and lingering grass, toffee and a little liquorice also.
Good beer. Taste is highly similar to that of a stout, but with slightly more complex flavors.

Location/Date:Bottle on June 17th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours black with white reddish head. 
Aroma: Aroma is malty caramel.  
Taste: Light bitterness, caramelly sweet that comes on in the middle and end.  Some roasty/nuttiniess.
Palate:Medium light body, faint fizz that isnt overpowering.
Summary: A lot of flavor in a beer that is only 5.5%. Enjoyable beer that is a malty alternative for spring that is somewhat light despite its looks.

super fruit and malty.
very well balanced with good hop profile and lovely lingering bitter sweet finish. deep flavour.
will probably have to rate again as i was a bit drunk!

bottle. wineways. harroagte

I really enjoyed this. In a state that thinks all bock beer starts with ShIner, this was a pleasant surprise. Aroma and taste had a very satisfying roasted maltiness. The palate was normal and appearance a dark brown with a thick head that slowly disappeared. Something worthy of a six pack because of its simplicity and straightforwardness.

355ml. bottle from Bitter Virtue, Southampton.
Pours a dark brown with a small head. Smells of roasty malt and chocolate. Tastes of dark chocolate, coffee, and malts. Bitter on the finish. Very nice.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $1.99 Very good.

12oz bottle from Armanettis. Pours a cloudy, darker brown colored body with a finger-width, frothy and creamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is slightly sweet caramel and toffee with a touch of breadiness. Some fruity esters, a light chocolate, a light earth, and a touch of roast. Flavor is fruity with some dark fruits and medium sweet caramels up front. Some toffee, a light bread, a light chocolate, a light earth, and a touch of roast in the middle before this finishes dry with some toast, a light roast, and a nice chocolate and caramel mix. Medium length aftertaste following a smooth, medium body and a moderate carbonation. Overall, not a bad bock. The initial fruitiness is a bit much for me, but the malts are nice with a solid caramel, toffee, and light chocolate flavor. Some roasts and a light earth keeps things interesting.

Dark color with a quick settling white foamy head. Dried fruits and chocolate flavor with a soft mouthfeel 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle courtesy of FaithHealer1. Dark brown with a big thick fluffy off-white head. Dried fruits, dark chocolate, slightly vanilla nose. Surprisingly dry front, some lager malt flavours, tobacco, wood, touch of roast malts, dark chocolate and some nice spiced bitterness on the finish. Not bad at all, though the taste doesn?t quite match up to the nose.
Bottle @ Bierzwerg.de. BB 12/12. Pours dark brown with a ruby edge and a creamy head. Tobacco, caramel, port, chocolate and dark fruit. A bit dusty. Quite complex. Smooth.

Pours a barely transparent dark cinnamon brown with a thick and rather persistent fine-bubbled beige head. Strong, malty aroma has an overtone of wet grass and hints of caramel and cinnamon. Flavor has a malty core plus a strong grassy note and tones of wood plus hints of caramel and cinnamon. Did they use grass clippings for hops? (But seriously, folks.) Still, it is a drinkable and enjoyable beer with a strongly hoppy but not bitter finish and a good amount of body and fizz.
12oz bottle poured into snifter. Very dark brown color with a thin bubbly head. Aroma and flavor is pretty much run by the malts. Slightly sweet with hints of brown sugar and caramel. Tasty.

12 ounce bottle into pilsener glass, bottled 1/18/2012.  Pours crystal clear reddish brown color with a nice 1-2 finger dense tan head with fantastic retention that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Some decent lacing on the glass, with plenty of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of light chocolate, biscuit, toasted malt, apricot, fig, raisin, caramel, molasses, and herbal hops.  Nice aromas, with a good amount of balance and decent strength.  Taste of caramel, chocolate, biscuit, raisin, fig, prune, molasses, toasted malt, and herbal hops.  Nice balance of flavors with a decent amount of robustness; and no cloying sweetness.  Medium carbonation and body; with a slight creamy and very smooth mouthfeel.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming present at all on the finish.  Overall this is a very nice and enjoyable bock.  Nice toasted flavors with good balance, and very smooth to drink.  A nice session beer candidate.

Much stronger and more bitter than traditional bock beers.  Clear dark ruby amber with a light head and lace.  The taste begins as traditional "bock" caramel malt, but is quickly overcome by hop bitterness that carries through to the finish.  A decent beer, but more like an American Porter or Stout.

Poured into pint glass. Nice huge head, really dark red. The nose is heavy malts, some caramel, cocoa, nuts. This is very rich! Nice chocolate malty flavors, some coffee, and some spice. Reminds me of a bitter Guinness. Not bad..

355ml bottle. Malty and sweet aromas. Pours dark brown, with thin tan head, nopersistent, poor lacework. Medium body and low carbonation. Taste is malty, some notes of caramel. Correct finish.
Not my favourite Anchor.
Very malty in both taste and flavor. Pours dark with minimal head. Has a definite bite that stays through the aftertaste.
From old backlog. Dark brown colour with medium head. Caramel, malt, toffee flavours. Tasty!

Rich like a black forest cake. Aroma of sweet malts, some honey, licorice, and a little roasty bready malts. dark brown pour with a white head that dissipated very quickly. Molasses, honey, and bread in the flavor, towards the end of the pint, things got a little too sickly sweet for me, the sugars dominate the flavor.
Looks like a dark lager, not too much on the nose, but then malty lager flavours. Bit disappointing

Single bottle purchased from Zyn Liqour in Calgary, AB on 04/02/2012. Colour: Near black with slightly off-white head. Nose: Heavy on the dark grains and bread, completely dominant. Traces of burnt malt. Taste: Medium light sweet, medium bitter, light sour. The burnt malt from the taste plays a bigger role on the palate. There are traces of raw green vegetable. The sweetness is more sugary than caramel or butterscotch. Drinkable but not outstanding.
Malt and roast in the aroma.  Flavor is sweet, with toffee, caramel, coffee, and nut flavors.  Ample carbonation gives a creamy mouthfeel.  This is a real treat.

12oz bottle from The Beerhive in Pittsburgh.  All too often the word "bock" is associated with swill, or the bottom of the barrel left over nastiness.  Here we can taste the handcrafted goodness and the care and attention Anchor has put into their first effort at this style.  Malty, medium bodied and well balanced; sure to please those who prefer things on the darker side of the menu.

12 ounce bottle - $1.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia. The bottle code "2JR" on the back should translate out to a bottling date of: January 18th, 2012.

Appearance: Pours out a dark reddish-brown body with a tall, albeit collapsing, beige head, though it never quite dissipates fully.

Smell: Near-blackened toast, small handful of roasted malt hinting at less-than-desirably coffee, a sliver of soiled fruit skin, and damp, dead leaves snatched out of a gutter.

Taste: Heavily toasted bread crusts, a sip of watered down, stale coffee, and a lone drop of molasses. Not much sweetness present. Very slight estery fruitiness, almost an incredibly faint tartness present as well. Leafy, lightly earthy hops with enough bitterness to balance, which isnt much. Earthy, toasted nut finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation.

Overall: Just lacking and a bit strange all around, one of my least favorite Anchor products.

On tap. It pours a dark amber color with a tan head. The aroma is very nice with toasted malt, cocoa, molasses and some fig. The flavor is dry and crisp with notes of unsweetened molasses, cocoa powder and a firm spicy bitterness near the finish. Medium bodied and rich flavors.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2014 Dark brown with a decent tan head.  Nice malt aroma of coffee and molasses.  Excellent balance of hops and malt with a lingering hop bitterness. A little on the sweet side.  Medium mouthfell with a filling finish.  One of the best American bocks Ive had.
Bottle. Sweet molasses malt aroma.  Brown with a small tan head. Light sweet malt, charred toast, and a lingering bitter flavor.Medium body with a slightly dry finish..

Anchor Bock Beer
Filed under: Beer Reviews  Leave a comment
April 8, 2012

Anchor Bock Beer is a 5.5% ABV Dunkler Bock by style brewed at Anchor Brewing in San Francisco, California. A Dunkler Bock is a typically copper to dark brown lager with nutty and toasted flavors and typically no hop taste or aroma.

Pouring out a dark somewhat opaque brown with bright amber highlights in the body and a thick foamy beige head. The foam disperses quickly as steady carbonation cascades upwards in the body and rests as a thin bubbly cap. The nose has sweet caramel and toasty malts with nutty aromas. There is no hop present in the aroma, but I do notice light floral and yeast based fruit notes. An overall sweet and light aroma.

The first sip I took got mostly toasted malts, light chocolate and a hint of underlying sweetness. Not too much going on mid palate, but the finish has a caramel richness and a light floral yeast. Like in the aroma, I get no hop presence in the taste.

12oz brown bottle. Dark brown with brassy deep orange highlights, clear. Fluffy tan head, streaky lacing. Nose has chocolate and caramel. Taste has chocolate and caramel, light hops in the finish. Noble hops in the aftertaste with some deep toasted malt. Medium body with strong carbonation. Well executed and sessionable.

Bottle: Pours a dark coffee color with ruby tones and a thin off-white head that is mostly lasting. Malty aroma and rich flavor is roasty with hints of caramel and chocolate. Has a creamy mouthfeel with a mild dry finish. Delicious!

Deep copper, tight off white head. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malt, light fresh citrus, cereal. Full bodied, chewy palate. Flavors of chocolate, dried cherries, sherry, cereal malt, coffee. Sweet and substantial, with a crisp lagerish finish.
Great Bock beer. Aroma of malt, coffee and caramel. Similar taste with even stronger coffee notes and hints of chocolate. Very drinkable.
Pour is dark brown with small tan lacing. Aroma is light caramel and roasted malts. Tastes heavily of cream and roasted coffee malts. Good bock.

Pours a deep dark brown with a medium brown lasting head, good lacing. Aroma of toasted caramel malt, yeast, dark fruity esters and light hops. Taste is sweet toasted caramel malt, yeast, some light chocolate flavors, dark fruits and lightly hopped. Palate is a medium body with light carbonation and a smooth mouth feel. Finish is sweet toasted caramel malt some notes of cacao, dark fruits, yeast ending is light hops bitterness for balance. Overall a good tasty, enjoyable and nicely balanced brew.
Dark brown colour. Aroma of carob. Taste is sweet, malty, carob, dark fruits. Nice.
Draft at sharp edge creek house. Pours really dark brown with an inch of white head. Has kind of a licorice thing on the nose. Nice spice tone on the tongue. Finishes clean. Flavorful beer.

pours clear dark brown with a thick off white head and some lacing.  rich, malty aroma. taste is nuts, caramel, and a hint of smoke.  finish is woody with a touch of licorice.  a really nice, spicy bock.
Bottle.  Dark brown pour.  Light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, vanilla, toffee, and raisins.  Taste is dried dark fruits and a slight bitterness.  Body is at a light to medium level.

Dark red/amber, full tan head.  Cherries and roasted malt in the nose.  Sweet and dark on the tongue, full bodied and soothing with a malty sweet finish.  This is  a delicious full bodied beer that is made for hearty food.

Pours dark opaque reddish brown. Small wispy head with a floral grassy malty aroma. Nice appearance ! Taste is somewhat complex with an even balance of hops and malt. Alcohol appreciated even at an ABV of 5.5 %. Finish is dry and short and somewhat astringent. Quaff Score 6 / 10
Pours a red brown with a brown head and sweet, malty aroma. Taste is sweet and toasty, with flavors of roasted malt, hops chocolate and alcohol. Drinkable, good brew from Anchor.
Pours medium brown color with tan head. Aromas of dark fruit and caramel. Toasted malt flavor with some raisins and dates. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Pours an opaque dark brown with mahogany edges, foamy light tan head fades leaving foam all over the glass. Aroma of dark fruits, chocolate and rich toasty malt. Taste is also very rich malty, some milky sweetness, a bit of dark fruit, light roasty finish. Very easy to drink,  Medium body, soft carbonation. However, Tastes more like a Brown Ale than a Bock. Very tasty, but just not getting the "Bock" feel.

Dark brown almost back with 3 finger tan head. Smells a sweet bready malts with a little fruit. Taste is much like it smells with a nice bitter chocolate after taste. Mouthfeel is very light and thin with a little carbonation.

12oz bottle. Nice, foamy tan head. Clear dark brown/red color. Moderate carbonation. Good lace. Roasty taste. Aroma of toasted dark-bread and chocolate malts. OK bock, not memorable. Decent for the style - I dont really think I care for dunkler bocks, though.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a clear very dark brown with a thick one finger tan head. Great head retention.

Smells of raisins and cocoa along with a little bit of licorice.

The flavor is slightly sweet and roasty with a little bit of tartness. Black licorice is there along with a touch of citrus. There is some caramel is well and everything cleans up with a light bitterness. Mouthfeel is pretty thick and creamy but the finish is fairly dry.

Overall this a pretty tasty and interesting beer. Doesnt taste like other bocks out there but is good in its own right.

A nice, very earthy bockbier with stingy molasses and iron flavors with dusty, peppery hop in the aroma and flavor. Sweet but not overly so. Light bitterness. Incredibly great carbonation, deep dark brown color and tight head = fab presentation. Easy to drink.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle, poured into a dimpled mug.  Very dark in color, dark ruby red.  Aroma is licorice, butterscotch, and vanilla cake frosting.  Carbonation is a bit fizzy for the style.  Taste is wheaty tang at first, then cocoa powder and sweet roasty malt with more licorice on the finish.  Nice and solid, enjoyed.

Bocks are interesting because the flavor it creates is so hard to put your foot on, I had this last year and going from 2010 to 2011 its just as I remember it, which is, hard to describe: Pours a dark mahogany that light barely gets through with an off-white foamy head that stays on as lacing. Smells strongly like a bock, which is like this dark wheat/hay smell with a little alcohol. Pretty thick bodied, taste like smell described but much more water downed. That deep hay with a little sweetness but despite the strong smell it doesnt taste so strong. No strong hop presence finishes with a grassy malt. Im not a big fan.

Sweet Caramel and Toffee flavors are balanced out by a strong roasted malts backbone, which may be a bit too malty for some. Overall, it tastes awesome! It helps set the mood for more spring-seasonal beers to come.

Bottle @ Timbers, Denver. Pours very dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, nuts, bit of hops. Taste is malt, toast, burnt caramel, grapefruity hops. Medium body, soft carbonation, dry finish. 280212

Bottle, 
this beer had a clear dark brown (ruby when held up to a light)  pour and made a two finger light tan colored head, this beer was pretty dark except at he bottom of the glass and I could see a center stream of bubbles there and there were a few bubbles flowing up the sides of the glass, this beer left spots and fingers of lacing on the glass, there was no sediment in the bottle, 

the aromas were faint chocolate and coffee, toasted malt and bread, malt and bread like sweetness with faint caramel, 

there were flavors of toasted read, chocolate, bread and caramel sweetness, the finish had a little bitterness, 
this drink started with a little sweetness and ended dry, 

the mouth feel was less than medium and had some creaminess on the palate, 

a beer with a nice nose and flavor, I thought there were interesting chocolate and coffee notes in this drink.

Looks beautiful in glass. Dark with red highlights. Nice thick off white head that hangs around. Very reminiscent of a good porter except that warm, sherry like note.  Nice full body, goes down smooth. Worth picking up a bottle to check out. 

---some day, I hope to have tried them all.

This seems to taste more like a traditional stout rather than a bock. Flavor is a solid combination of hops and malt. It could be smoother on the palate.There is a slight hint of grape, some spiciness, and a flavor of peat.

Bottle @ home. Deep brown appearance with a light brown head. Super toasty, burnt bready, creamy, nutty aroma. Creamy, burnt, toasty malty, nutty, a touch charred flavor. I havent had this one in a few years but its not as good as I remembered.
23 feb 2012, bottle. dark brown, clear. bready, meaty, tartness with dark coffee notes. med/thin body and fizzy. burnt coffee, dark bread, some burnt malt notes. pretty good bock beer.

Bottle. It pours a dark amber color with a tan head. The aroma is very nice with toasted malt, cocoa, molasses and some fig. The flavor is dry and crisp with notes of unsweetened molasses, cocoa powder and a firm spicy bitterness near the finish. Medium bodied and rich flavors. Nice one.
Aroma is dark chocolate and caramel.  It poured a dark brown with a brown head.  Taste is sweet malt with a little bitter.  Full body beer.

Im comparing what I sense to what it "ought" to be (i.e., the style). What I had was a bit different from this. Id say its definitely its own, but pretty much there anyway - the city mentioned on the label certainly makes this so! Anyway, its more dry than sweet and quite toasty. I enjoyed the aroma of sweet toastiness the most and although it could have tasted sweeter, with a bit more nuttiness (or maybe I shouldve ate some cashews during this process), the dryness was pleasant. I recommend this as a Bay Area Bock.

Appearance was clean root beerish with red hues. 2 finger tannish head was long creamy with plently of lacing.Aroma was sweet fig,choco, coffee, and loads of malts, no hints of alcohol. Taste was like the smell,nutty coffee with slight herbal piney hops and little taste alcohol. Mouthfeel was velvet body with tight  creamy carbonation, a long malty finish. Warmer it  gets the more alcohol comes through. A beauty...
draft - pours dark brown with caramel head.  Nose is coffee.  Taste is balanced but mainly bitter.
Clear brown with a tan head.  Roast and spice (liquorish) aroma.  Taste lightly sweet malt with wood, rye and liquorish with a dry finish.   Way too dry to be a bock.

Deep brown with a steady tan head. Roasted coffee aroma. Malty, slightly soapy, tea/coffee bitter, tones of smoke/burnt wood,  DRY finish.  First drink is strong, but it mellows out nicely. Some berry-ness at the end....not a bad offering at all.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a medium head. Aroma caramel, spices, malts.   Brown sugar and some spices dominate the taste. Medium body, and carbonation. Not Bad.

355ml bottle

Pours dark brown with a medium beige head. Aroma of chocolate, cookies, caramel malts and coffee. Taste is quite malty and bready with notes of rye, caramel and sweet syrup. Finish has bitter and malty notes. Okay, well balanced bock.

Malzschokoladiger und zitrusangehauchter Geruch. Malzig-dichter Antrunk. Mittelteil schokoladig, bitter-zitrusartig. Röstiger, bitterschokoladiger Ausklang bei nachlassender Zitrusnote; trockenbitter. Gut.

12oz bottle.  Really the least exciting Anchor offering that I can remember.  Pours out a nice dark brown to ruby hue.  Aromas are quite malty, some sharp notes that remind me of lush fruits, roasty and bitter notes as well.  Palate is smooth, but providing a really interesting sharp roasted coffee bitterness.  Much more full bodied than I expected.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle. This is absolutely delicious. Dark brown pour with a monster clingy foamy reddish-brown head. Huge molasses, chocolate, and red wine nose. Smooth medium palate with some carbonation. Taste is malt, mild chocolate, some fruitiness, and some roastiness. Just excellent all the way around - would love to see this with the carbonation toned down just a touch and the palate heft kicked up just a touch.
This beer was very good nice and malty not to over the top i would buy this beer again.

Colabrown beer with a medium, beautiful, thick and light brown head. Aroma is malty, berries, strawberries, nice aroma. Taste is also malty, berries, some roasted malts, more bitterness than usually at bocks, and bitterness is sightly wooden. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, however, less carbonation could be better. Quite nice beer, but I expected more because of great brewer. Malty and surprisingly, lots of berries in this bock.
Bottle @ home. Aroma is sweet burned caramel, some christmas like spices. Flavour is dry roasted malt, some deep burned malt, touch of coffee, hint of spices. Roasty and dry bock. Okay.
Bottle at home. Dark brown pour, reddish hue and a thin off-white head. Aroma is roasty, some mocha, dark fruits and red wine. Flavor is slightly sweet, bready and some bitter. A bit rough.

Appearance:  murky brown with maroon highlights and a rich, one-finger tan head.   Aroma: molasses, toasted malts, some graham cracker.   Taste: toasted dark malts, caramel, strong notes of molasses and brown bread, hint of cherry.  Finish: creamy, smooth and dry, with a noticeable dusty flavor at the last.   Notes: Not quite as sweet as Id expect from a bock, and I didnt care for the pronounced dusty flavor at the end, but the palate was incredible:  silky smooth, rich and full without being cloying.

35,5 cl bottle @ home, BBE 12/2012
Flavour is rather interesting mix of American hops and roasted malt typical to bocks. Exotic fruits and hints of coffee, chocolate, licorice and berry juice. Flavour is hoppy too with exotic fruits at the beginning and finish with coffee, chocolate and licorice. Also Anchor house flavour is present. A bit thin palate. Really not your typical bock but rather unique and nice, especially when looking at the ABV.

355 ml bottle. BBE 12/2012.
Pours a deep mahogany colour with a thick beigeish head. Aroma of strong American hops and sweet toasted malts - really good. Flavour of pleasant sweet toasted malts, American hops, sweetish berries, milk chocolate and light coffee. Medium bodied, very soft carbonation and smooth mouthfeel. Finish of bitter American hops, chocolate and some fruitiness. Extremely well balanced and kudos for the low ABV.

Bottled 355ml. Appearance: Beautiful mahogany with a remarkably creamy, tall (especially for the style), mountainous light beige head. Some nice lacework. Aroma: Huge amounts of Cascade, caramel and mocha. Rather inviting. Taste and palate: Medium bodied. Great balance. Very pleasant coffee components. Vanilla sneaking in. Dry. Lovely bittering hop profile. Some tar showing up. Very faintly salty. Dryish finish which makes you eager to take another sip. Overall impression: Very tasty. Not a typical german dunkler bock in any case- and I was expecting a very different interpreation. Cascade hops have been used? Delicious.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into a tall glass.

Appearance: Dark brown with foamy cream-colored head and lots of lacing.

Aroma: Cherry, caramel, bread, some metal and spicy hops.

Taste: Caramel, cocoa, bread, and fruity malts with a nice juxtaposition of spicy and metallic hop bitterness.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, medium body, clean lager finish that is somewhat dry.

Overall: Very nice Bock overall, with a rich malt flavor and nice hop bite. Another winner from Anchor.

Bottle. Aroma is of a bock, somewhat roasted coffee/toffee. Surprising taste considering...definitely a surprise beer. Well balance roasted taste. Would drink again!  Surprised by the low abv, I woulda guessed 6-7%. 5.5% alcohol. (so many uses of the word surprise...but its true! Gg, Anchor!)

Dark brown color with a fine creamy head. Smells of roasted malts and caramel, with a massive malt body. Starts with lots of roasted malts, coffee and caramel, in the background slightly chocolatey. Overall, with strong malt body. The middle part is also dominant malty, with chocolate and roasted coffee flavors. In the background a nice hop aroma comes through. Goes into a dry, bitter, malty, roasty finish with a lot of coffee flavor

Bottle. Pours deep black brown with big tan cream head. Roast, pine, citrus, dark malts with a big caramel toffee on the end of the nose. Med light body creamy mouthfeel, touch of toast among the deep rich malts, Chocolate - sweetness lingers through the end.

Bottle.  Aroma is a sweet chocolate balanced with malts.  Brown color, clear, but dark, tan, thin head.  Relatively smooth but ic an feel the carbonation which changes the feel.  Tste is balance and brings out the malt.  Seems like a good beer".. Not a big fan of this style.

355 ml bottle. BBE 12/2012.
Pours dark red colour with large beige head. Aroma of liquorice, berries, roasted malts, caramel and light peated chocolated. Flavour of mild salty liquorice, salmiac, roasted malts, light fruits, caramel and ashy chocolate. A lot better than the previously tasted bottle.
