355 ml bottle @ The Rake.
Rated on 20110719. (6+3+7+3+14)
Dark brown colour with medium foamy head and some lacing. Aroma is dark malts, grass and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malts, fruits, chocolate and some bread. Medium carbonation, medium-bodied, some sourness on the palate. Balanced.
4324

Dark enticing pour with nice tan foam and fair lacing.  Aroma of malts match the flavor in the smooth flavor.  Just a touch of alcohol burn in the finish.  Very nice and something I will keep an eye out for in the future.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown color with reddish undertones and a one inch tan head that dissappates to a very substantial lacing.  Smell is malty with some sweet toasted notes, along with some faint earthy and grassy tones in the background.  Taste is very malty, somewhat sweet, with some hints of that dark fruit.  Finish has a very dry but light hop. Mouthfeel is smooth and mellow.

Bottle from Martins in Mt. Laurel, NJ.  Clear chestnut brown under a short khaki head.  Sweet malty aroma.  Flavor of malt, bread, cinnamon, and maybe apples with a rich caramel ribbon.  Silky mouthfeel and a well-balanced, sweet finish.

The aroma is similar to Celebrator in that its malty without much sweetness, although this seems more subdued than Celebrator.  The appearance is dark amber/brown.  The flavor has almost a coffee flavor to it and has a slight bitterness to it.  This was different from what I was expecting, it was almost similar to a porter in flavor, a pretty good dunkler bock overall.

Curious beer. Pours dark brown, almost black. Nose is roasted malt, caramel, herby/spicy. Taste is oddly balanced for me. Mouthful is light and watery, taste is roasted, malty, dry. Not much fruit or body.
Bottle. Very dark brown with medium tan head. Flavour is malt, chocolate, caramel, hops, bitter, roasted malts, nuts and dark fruit.
Pours a very dark brown with a tan head. Almost looks like a porter than a bock. Has a deep malty flavor that finishes dry. Has a touch of sweetness.

A very dark brown with a tan big head. Pleasant malty aroma with nuts, nougat, grassy hops and peach. Smooth body thats quite bitter actually like a porter. Especially the dryness in the finish reminds me more of an American stout than a German dunkelbock. Just refreshing enough. Well brewed; not fully my taste. (355cl bottle)

bottled. pours dark brown with a tan tight head. aromas of chocolate, burnt malt and vanilla. mildly bitter and earthy. astringent and moderate bodied. it lingers with burnt malt on the tongue. not my favorite.

Bottle from Bierzwerg. Poured dark brown with a white head. Caramel and hops in aroma, spicy notes as well, but can´t figure out what spices. Flavour is caramel and some roasted malt, dark fruity. Hops in finish, which is quite dry. Strange brew, but quite interesting.

Bottle 355ml, a dark beer with a good brownish head. Nose is on dark chocolate, barley wine like. Aroma is dry with intense bitter chocolate body with a slightly vinous note, intense dark malt aftertaste. What a rich body and perfume for a low alcohol level, not too astringent, good brew.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with tan/brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, dried cherries, earth.  Flavor is chocolate, raisin, peat, toasty.  Finish is dry with flavors of cacao and molasses.  I really enjoy this Dunkler Bock.

[Bottle] Pours a chestnut brown color with fine carbonation but no head. Caramel, vanilla and hazelnut notes mix with a generally roasted nose. Cocoa powder, dark fruits, maple syrup and figs in the taste. Crisp hop finish. Very nicely balanced. Quite tasty and sessionable.

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on June 13 2011; eye: mahogany, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of creamy beige head, no lacing; nose: malt, molasses; mouth: malt, molasses, liquorice, fig, thin finale in molasses with presence of malt, medium body, below-average carbonation, mildly sweet, sticky texture; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 13 juin 2011; il : acajou, claire, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige crémeuse, pas de dentelle; nez : malt, mélasse; bouche : malt, mélasse, réglisse, figue, finale mince en mélasse avec présence de malt, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture collante; en résumé : correct
Bottle. Ruby brown, with tan head. Aroma - rich malt. Taste - Rich, complex biscuity malt, some caramel, slightly nutty. Well carbonated. Dry malt finish

12 oz. bottle Pours a dark dark red, almost black.  Lower amounts of carbonation and a thin off white head. The taste is earthy and not like a german bock, it is very different. It has some chocolate and raisin notes and some green earthy hops. There is a pretty clean finish and it is a lot to chew on but a little thin on the back end. I liked it but not wild about it.
I love this beer with steak.  Its everything you would expect from a bock, but a little malty aftertaste.

Used a snifter from a bottle. Deep brown, damn near black. Thick fluffy full, off white head thats lasts to the end. Full sheets and layers of lace. Great eye appeal. Nose is dark fruit, raisins and barely. Flavor is very earthy taste. Nuts, barley, caramel, light chocolate. Finish a little thin for a bock. but still pretty damn good.  This isnt a style I have much experience with.  It MUST be on the higher end of a Dunkler Bock. Ok, brew.

Keg at North Bar, Leeds. Very happy to have found this, was eager to try it. Not disappointed, quite a remarkable beer. Rather lovely deep red-black colour, wonderful aroma: toasty, chocolatey, almost raisin-y. Tastes wonderful - again toasty, dark fruity, manages to be sweet but bitter at the same time, again like dark chocolate. Beautifully, beautifully done, balances itself and juxtaposes itself brilliantly. Very impressed.
8th June 2009Clear dark brown beer. Crispish palate. Rich malt with a distinct marmite tone and a little bitter hop fruit in the finish. Not bad but a tad bitter.

Nice brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, dark fruit, & some caramel; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, raisons, and some chocolate; Finish is slightly sour/tart; Nicely balanced; Overall, quite good.
Keg at The North Bar, Leeds. Dark brown with ruby hue, cream head. Really quite sweet and fruity, plummy, strawberry with hints of dark roasted malts. Just too overly sweet for me.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a thick rich tan head. Aroma is of rich dark malt or maple syrup and brown sugar. Taste is very briefly sweet followed by roasted dark malt. It finishes with a bit of lingering sourness.

Tar pour with a moussey, nicotined swell of foam. Then the aroma; a saliva-making, deeply malty confection of molten Curly-Wurly, figs, carob draped with toffee sauce, a rub of orange, black pepper. Smells like Youngs Chocolate blended with a top doppelbock. Flavour has no chance of matching it, but has a go; soapy hop, sour dabs, dark figgy fruit dusted with burnt wood, the booze-sodden bottom of a trifle. Some English coal smoke and nutmeg-sprinkled dough (yeast?). Hop greenery on the burp for good measure. A winner, let down only by its fizziness.
Deep flavor of malt with nuts, caramel, and roastiness throughout. Very nice, not at all bitter, somewhat sweet.

12oz. bottle.  Remarkable and intriguing aroma, with notes of dark, toasty, bready, lightly sweet malts, spruce, molasses, dried fruits, dark berry, almond, earthiness, even some faint herbal spiciness.  Rich, dark, clear red-brown color, head is light tan, fine, uneven and lasting.  Flavor profile is surprisingly dry and bitter (for the style, that is), with several features carried over from the aroma, including the dark, dusty, grainy, bready, nutty malts, the sweetness only showing as a faint accent around the edges, otherwise moving towards herbal, leafy hop, peppery spice, faint cocoa and earthy aspects as the flavor progresses.  Finish is darkly fruity, tangy and dry.  Low to moderate effervescence, rather light in feel and very drinkable, body is medium.  Surprisingly, this has some features that I have otherwise found in Our Special Ale.  Really tasty and satisfying.
Pours a dark brown color with a light brown head.  Smells like chocolate and also tastes like chocolate.  Pretty good.

(bottle) pours a clear dark ruby colour with a billowing frothy brown head. heavy aroma of dark fruit, sweet spices and brown sugar, light milk chocolate and liquorice. flavour is mostly the same, with a dry roasted-maltiness coming through in the finish, accompanied by burnt toast and a hint of mushrooms. body is watery, with average carbonation.

Bottled from Bierzwerg. Dark chocolate color with thick beige creamy head. dark chocolate, raisins, plums, glove in aroma. Taste, dark chocolate, blackberries, caramel, raisins, some spices. Bitter finish.  very nice beer.

Pours nicely out of Anchors shortie bottles.  Thin head, but nice dark carmelly color.  A vague hoppy smell (or is it new spring weather?)  A touch of sweetness, with heavier bitter notes at the end.
355ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a large head.  Aroma is burnt caramel malt and a little apple.  Taste starts with some toffee malt.  Watery coffee, caramel finish.
Pours brown and smells of liquid bread.  Spice and sweet notes with the rich malt backbone.  Similar flavor profile with a touch of hops to add for a slightly bitter finish.  Solid fasting beer.
12 oz bottle from Mainbrew - Darker than I expected with a nice tan head.  Aromas of caramel, licorice.  A little more bitter than I would like.  Not a hoppy bitter.  Its OK.  One is enough.

Bottle: Very deep amber coloured, bigger stable tanned head; moderate to solid dryish toasty-fruity (dried berries) nose with a vinous touch; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied; increasing hoppiness towards the moderate to solid fruity-toasty finish. Good, good.....

Bottle at PINT Meibockfestival 11. Dark brown colour, beige head. Aroma of liquorice, laurel, caramel, roasted malts. Flavour is lots of laurel and liquorice (drop), roasted malts, some caramel, sticky liquorice and light hoppy bitter finish. Medium bodied.

Pours dark brown with tan head, diminishing quickly. Aroma is roasty, burnt caramel, cocoa, nutmeg and date. Flavor is relatively sweet up front with with the date flavor and some cocoa coming through - notes of tobacco match the roasty maltiness. Finishes on the bitter side. Medium bodied, average carbonation - a flavorful Bock, which is not typically my first choice in style.

(12 ounce bottle - Tumbler glass)  Pours a dark ruby color with a huge head.  Aroma is of herbal hops and nutty caramel malt.  Medium to heavy sweetness and light bitterness.  Mouthfeel has a soft to flat carbonation.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a thick, foamy light brown head that sticks around for quite a while and laces very nicely. Aroma is malty, roasty, with some dark fruit, caramel. Taste is fairly full bodied and flavorful, taste is more malty with some chocolate. Finish is dry and malty. A very solid bock.

A dark brown pour with crimson edges and a tan head.  It has a malty aroma filled with caramel and cherry.  The medium body has a somewhat sticky texture and lively carbonation.  The taste is sweet at first then adds some mild bitterness before the slightly dry finish.

(bottle, 35.5cl) Clear, dark brown colour with a ruby shine and a dense and thick tanned foamy head. Dark malty aroma with notes of caramel, chocolate, herbs and nuts, accompanied by a tinge of dried fruits. Roasty bitter and slightly sweet flavour, medium to light bodied with a pleasant carbonation. Dark and roasted malt-character with an almost dry mouthfeel, notes of caramel and chocolate with herbal hops; bitter and slightly sweet roast-malty finish with dark chocolate in the aftertaste. Pleasant. 08.IV.11

On tap for growler fills at Half Time.  Pours a clear ruby tinged brown with a medium beige head.  Toast and sweet caramel on the nose.  Malty and lightly floral, chocolate and cocoa notes.  Medium bodied, toast and chocolate, sweet caramel and toast.  Sweet malt, crisp and smooth.  Nice toasty bitterness on the finish.

On tap.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of buttery notes, roast, and sweet malt.  Flavor is sweet and quite fruity (strawberry in particular) with raisin and dark fruits.  Too sweet and the flavor profile was not to my liking.
6/4/5/3/11 [2.9/5]

355 ml bottle, from the foreign beer bar at the Darlington Spring Thing Beer Festival 2011. ABV is 5.5%. Mahogany to dark ruby colour, big beige head. Malty aroma with notes of Schwarzbrot and caramel. The flavour is also very malty with notes of caramel and brown bread, very moderate hops. Nice enough to drink.

On tap at Coles  
Aroma darker malts, mellow aroma, slight gentle roast. 6-
 Appearance  dark brown, creamy top. Fizzy center.
Flavor and Palate : Smooth, medium bodied brew. Slight roast malty notes , creamy DMS like follow up. Low carbonation for lager. Passable but just enough. Dark malts, thin body, some alcohol.

Trader Joess, DC single ($1.42): Pours a darkish red brown color with a tan head. Aroma is slight roasted malts with some fruit aromas in there as well. Slightly sweet. Got a bitter finish. Really German flavors shining through better than most American bocks.Got some bread going up in there. Liqueur flavors and the like. Good stuff and very drinkable.

Bottle from Breeze Thru.  Pours foamy mahongany with a brown head.  Great lacing.  Aroma is cocoa, caramel, toffee and raisins.  Taste is roasted malts, cocoa, caramel and vanilla.  Finishes a bit thin and quite sweet.  Big fan of the aroma, unfortunately it does not carry through fully on that promise.
A dark beer with a light head. Taste of malts, dark chocolate. Moderate carbonation. Would drink this beer again!

Bottle. Deep brown with a huge foamy light tan head. Aroma of dark rye bread, some chocolate and a bit of raisin. The flavor is lots of dark bready malt with a bitterness in the background just for balance. Medium body with average carbonation and a smooth mouth feel. This is a nice beer every once in a while, just not super drinkable IMO.

Appearance:  Pours a deep dark brown with a think creamy beige cap atop.

Aroma: Very similar spices and dark fruits I find in Anchor OSA. Magical. Caramelized figs.

Taste: Caramelized dark fruit, cardamom, dark chocolate, pumpernickel. Finishes with burnt sugar and a berry twang.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, modest carbonation.

Overall:  A masterpiece of a beer. Fruity like the Anchor Porter and OSA, but still unique to the other two.

A very nice dark mahogony color.  Almost looks brown.  Some ruby highlights piercing through.  A light tan head that looked very smooth and creamy.  A very full head with very, very nice retention and some pretty decent lacing.  The aroma provided almost buttermilk type notes.  Rich and malty.  Rather robust.  Tiny hints of lard.  Even getting touches of dark fruit.  It even smells rather sweet.  Maybe even a touch of chocolate.  The taste was a smooth, more of a dark fruit type flavor.  Nice malty touches.  This taste is super well balanced.  Low hop bitterness.  Somewhat toasty.  The "lard" taste is very well hidden.  Again maybe even a hint of chocolate.  Medium mouthfeel.  Super smooth.  Glides across the palate slickly.  Dry.  Coats the throat and tongue very nicely.  A bit more thin than what I was anticipating.  Im not real big on "Bock" beers, but this one is the best Bock I have had thus far.  Very well balanced in all aspects.  Very easily drinkable.  I would have no problem drinking this.  Very sessionable and worth a try.
Clean roasty dark malts, medium bodied with some creamy feel, hints of molasses. Its a beer thats less than sum of its parts but its a solid and flawless keeper.
Pour deep ruby garnet, tan head. Aroma caramel, brown sugar, earthiness. Taste caramel, toffee, nutty, brown sugar, mild hopping, a slight burnt taste. MF slightly thin medium carb. Overall meh.

Pours opaque dark dark brown with mahogany edges, foamy light tan head fades leaving islands of foam. Aroma of dark fruits, chocolate and rich toasty malt. Taste is also very rich malty, some milky sweetness, a bit of tart fruit, light meaty roasty finish. Very easy to drink, great stuff. Medium body, soft carbonation.
Raisin and sweet malt nose. Cola brown, medium tan head, good lacing. Tart raisins and plum. Heavy on the fizz. Decent.

12oz. bottle. Pours a dark reddish with a thin light brown head. Aroma of caramel, molasses, raisins, and some earthy hops. Taste is caramel, brown sugar and dark fruit. Some hoppy resinous character in the finish with residual sweetness. Mouthfeel is medium heavy and fairly sticky.
Sample.  Pours deep brown, nice frothy tan head, lots of lacing.  Sweet matl aroma and taste.  Good stuff.

Pours a nice red brown color w/ a nice foamy head of evenly sized small bubbles. Sweet caramel dominates the nose, lots of raisin w/ a very slight toasty note. Flavor is similarly malt centric but the body isnt too heavy and the carbonation is sweet and creamy. There is a weird sort of charcoal and sour character in the background that sort of brings it down a bit. This is an OK beer w/ a small flavor flaw which makes it somewhat below average.

Pours dark brown with a two-finger-wide light brown head. Aroma is very nutty, with some sweet caramel/toffee thrown in. Flavor is somewhat thin, not nearly as good as the aroma. Very carbonated and not much flavor besides some slight bittersweetness in the finish.
Draught via waterfront.  Pored dark. Nutty aroma. Good consistency. Malty taste. Pretty well done imo.

12 oz bottle.  Pours deep, deep brown with a light brown head.  Aroma has lots of dark fruits, raisin and red grape, some molasses, toffee, and caramel.  Flavor has the dark fruits, toffee, and caramel, but leans more strongly into coffee and roasty territory.  This is really quite tasty.

The first American craft bock Ive opened this Spring. Pours beautiful deep brown color and a perfect head. Lacing is good, not too sticky.Great nose, lots of caramel and malt - similar to a porter. Palate is strange; lots of carbonation and thin. Very drinkable, but not really in a good way. Im a bit disappointed in how casual the beer is, but I guess Im just used to Dopplebocks. Flavor is good but not great. Quite bitter with hints of fennel.

Pours dark brown with a great brown head leaving a lots of lace. Aroma is roasted, sweet, malty, raisins, prunes and fidges. Lean sweet malty mouthfeel. Flavor is caraway, fennel, spicy, malty, hoppy and apples. Very drinkable with a thin body. Sweet sourish fruity palate. Finishes fruity sweet with a very pleasant dry tart aftertaste.

Bottle. Dark black color with a thick head that fades away leaving a nice lace on the top. Smells of fruit, chocolate and sugar. Tastes fruity and ginger with a malty backbone. Reminds me of the christmas ale a little. Not as heavy as it looks. Not what i expected for a bock but itd good nonetherless, and very drinkable. Nice brew from anchor.

Deep brown with red hues and yellow-tan head.  Great malty aroma, Munich malts, gingerbread, biscuit, dark fruit.  Non-cloying, sweet malt with dry, roast malt finish that lingers.  Medium body.  A little more roast and dry of a finish than I usually like in a bock...but still a great showing.

Pours a dark molasses brown with lots of tan foamy, lacy head on top that retained pretty well. Smell is of roasted grain, some dark fruits like currants or plums, with a hint of caramel sweetness as well. Taste is nice, with those dark currants coming through to go with a slightly phenolic, medicine taste that is nice. Aftertaste is slightly funky, but also pleasing. Caramel hits when needed, preventing too much phenolic/fruity/bitter tastes. This brew is full and well-bodied as is typical for the bock style, but right now this guy is hitting the spot even more than the average bock usually does. Just love how filling these beers are. Mouthfeel is great, with perfect carbonation and that body I was just talking about. Drinkability is awesome, dont see any end to me drinking this if I had a six pack on me right now. Love it.

Bottle. Deep dark brown colored in appearance with dense beige head. The aroma is a blend of butterscotch, toffee and toasted malt. The taste is mostly roasted malt and coffee in addition to caramel, toffee and lemon citrus toward the end. The finish is dry and roasty with a slight malt aftertaste. Its overall flavor is definitely a unique interpretation of the Bock style and is almost closer to a Stout or a Porter.

12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours dark brown with a thick beige head.  Aroma of bread, nuts, caramel, and a little spice.  Flavor similar, and it actually reminds me of Coca Cola with alcohol and a bit of malt flavor.  Average texture.  A good dunkler bock.

12 oz bottle: Pours deep mahogony in color with a nice tan head. Malty notes in the aroma with definite caramel, light roasted notes and some coffee coming through. Smooth, medium body with a semi-slick mouthfeel. A bit of molasses, roasted barley, and caramel with slight notes of coffee in the palate. Overall a really enjoyable beer, great for the cold winter days without it being too thick and chewy or complex. Overall: B+
This is a really nice brew.  Malty and chewy and really simple.  Nothing special about it but just good.  Would be perfect with stew or other meaty soups.

12 oz bottle from Bevmo. Pours a dark brown color with a medium beige head that slowly recedes to a fine ring. The aroma is strong with anise, chocolate, barley and black licorice. The flavor is similar to the aroma, nicely roasted grains, licorice, molasses, musty grapes and some chocolate. The palate is full and smooth with soft carbonation. The finish is long with lingering molasses. Overall: A very tasty bock.

Bottle. Pours a deep dark brown color with a thin tan head. Nice, malty aroma. Some roasted nuts in the background to go with some brown sugar. Light, dry taste. A hint of milk chocolate. Very smooth. A pretty impressive beer from Anchor!

Deep reddish-brown with a small beige head. Aroma is pretty sweet, with caramel malt, some fruitiness, wheat and a touch of hops. The flavor is somewhat plain: slightly sweet, slightly bitter, with a dull roasted taste that reminds me of a schwarzbier. Body is medium and a little fizzy. Not a bad beer, just lacking in the taste department.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown murky color with a small off white head. Nose is lightly nutty with dry roasted notes. Palate is smooth with a light dirty taste in the finish. Flavors of light nuts, roast malts, brown sugar.

Bottle at the Euston Tap. Pours a rich, reddish-brown with a warm, beige head. Sweet aroma with lightly roasted malts, some caramel, some yeast. Quite sweet flavor, malty, with ripe fruits and further caramel, along with moderate bitterness. Light to medium in body with average carbonation. Finishes sweet and malty with some lingering roast. Good stuff.
From bottle into small yard, pours a very dark, rich amber brown with a thick  carmel head. Tastes very rich, super subtle hop taste at first and then turning very spicy and malty.

A dark reddish-brown brew with nice frothy head that goes to lacing and hangs around a while. Good carbonation, light. Aroma is lightly sweet and roasty. Flavor is full range of malt roast toast and chocolate notes. Thinner mouthfeel than a porter. Somewhat tart and fruity in the middle. Finish is on the thinner side though.
Deep brown, but with good clarity. Malty, nutty with a smokey oak flavor. Somewhat bitter.

33 cl bottle, The Dram Shop, Sheffield, UK. All the way to Sheffield to find this. Deep ruby tinged brown, mostly malt on the nose with some raisin and plumb. Sweet flavour, lighter body than anticipated, some alcohol and prurnes on the finish.

12oz bottle.  been looking for this a long time.  pours a great looking muddy brown that turns bright ruby under a flashlight.  on top is a fluffy, whipped looking tan head.  aroma of toasty malts, burnt caramel and licorice.  flavor has lots of burnt caramel, licorice, nuts.  medium/light in the body with a moderate amount of carbonation.  fantastic!
Pours a dark ruby/brown with a nice tan head. Nose is chocolate, roasty malts, raisins and dark fruits. Taste is full but not complex.

Dark brown, good light tan head.  Aroma is heavy with brown sugar.  Taste is sweet and reminds me of toffee - or maybe some other candy that I cant bring to mind.  Finish is just a bit of bitterness with toasty and roasty flavors.  Ive never had this one and am very surprised at how good it is.

A style which I dont have a lot of experience with and does not get enough attention. Bottle poured into a a wide brimmed glass. Was darker than I thought with some red tinge and a hefty head. The aroma was a rich malt with some dried fruit like raisins, prunes and even some dried cherry. Rich caramel taste with a thin but satisfying texture. A top quality anchor offering.

Poured from bottle. Nose has caramel, light chocolate, fig, spice, and plum notes. Pours a dark brown with red highlights and an extremely solid head. Drinks rich but not at all sweet; elements of soy and herbs -- oregano? Kinda funky, but I like it. Goes down smoothly.

Bottle.  Pours reddish/brown with a slight brown head that recedes quickly.  Aromas of raisin, tobacco, and cherry.  Flavor is dark fruit; sweet, sugary, with nearly no hop presence.  A little thin in body.  Good.
Pours up a chocolate with a slight head. Smells like dark beer. Wow is that nutty. Do not like. Would not buy again. Do I have to finish this glass?

One of the finest bock beers. Goes great with bock bread. Tried it in Laughlin and one of the steak houses.

The special-release, super-high ABV, oak-aged-with-gold-leaf brews are great and all, but every once in a while, its nice to find an everyday beer with no obvious flaws.  Anchor Bock is just that - good and steady.

12oz pours a clear brown with a perfect-sized foamy khaki head that condenses to a dense little ring.  Aroma is a wacky mix of toffee, butterscotch, and sweet flowering berries.
