tasting on 5/8/10.  deep brown pour with a thin tan head... sweet malty nose with some fruit notes... medium to light body with raisins, grapes and sweet malts.  decent.
Heavy malt taste, definite toffee, roasty feel...nice thick head, almost no hops present

Aroma/Taste: Toffee, berries, fruits
Appearance: Very simple. A bit of head but not outrageous
Palate: Excellent. Fairly strong flavor but still went down easy.
Overall: One of the better bocks Ive tried. Im becoming a fan of Anchor

Pours deep dark and sassy brown. The head is a tan to copperish color with a slight lace. Malt, baking chocolate, and a light roast scent make the bouquet. The body is heavy and the mouthfeel is balanced with malty caramel flavors. The finish is lighter and abrupt.
Mixed berry nose. Pours chocolate. Complex taste of mild licorice, berry and marshmallow malt. Rated 4/10/10

Teak pour, mocha head. Nose is resplendent with Munich malt, plus hints of pomegranate and dirty/minty hops. Chalk dust, winey and molasses notes; smells oxidized. Tastes of tart blackberry, burnt sugar, butter, shiny new magazine, balsamic vinegar, prunes and dates- very, very fruity. Thickish and a little bit greasy on the tongue. Coffee and lemon rind aftertaste.

Aroma of chocolate, butterscotch and caramel. Appearance is dark brown with creamy tan head. Flavor similar to nose with cherries and confectionery sugar. Palate is bubbly and creamy. Another wonderful offering by Anchor.

Anchor Bock pours a beautiful shade of nut brown, a dark mahogany highlighted with maroon and mocha. The head is substantial and leaves good lacing. The aroma is sweet with some nuttiness, like a good, heavy pumpernickel or dark rye bread with a sprinkling of caramelized sugar. The malt is definitely the star. The beer really smells like bread; theres even a bakers yeast flavor lurking. The flavor is a bit sweet for my taste, but its far from bad. Its an aggressively malty beer, more of a bread in a glass style beer than most American bocks.
Pours a deep dark brown. Aromas of roasted malts, smoke, and hints of fruit. Flavors of the roasted malts, some fruit, with a coffee aftertaste.

A 12 oz. bottle yields a clear, dark rosewood colored beer with a decent tan head and minimal lacing.  The nose is dark roasted malt with some alcohol peeking through.  This is a fairly sweet beer, rich with dark dried fruit, caramel, chocolate and coffee in the mid-palate.  The beer is well-hopped and finishes quite dry.

12oz bottle from Whole Foods Los Altos.  Cant believe I hadnt tried this one yet - its the last of Anchors lineup I had left to try.

Pours a pretty clear dark ruby-chestnut color with a large tan head and good lacing.  This sure is a "dunkel" one.  Aroma is really excellent: caramel, chocolate, and toffee, as well as dark fruit (raisin) notes.  Complex.  Flavor is also nice.  Dark fruits - caramel and plum - are present, as well as chocolate, toffee, roast, and a little booze.  Medium-bodied with a smooth mouthfeel, very clean.  This is surprisingly good for a German-style American brew from a brewery that doesnt get enough fanfare for its quality lineup.  Will definitely revisit this one.

Pours cola brown with a huge late head.  Aroma is faint coffee with toffee into malty sweetness.  It smells like a delicious piece of chocolate.  It is tight in the mouth with a pronounced maltiness rolling over the tongue.  It is easy to drink.  Welcome Spring.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling
It pours a tea like color with a huge, pillowy, light tan head.  There is excellent head retention and nice lacing left behind.  The nose is filled with malt and a nice resiny hop note.  The taste is a mix of pale malt, a little alcohol, some spice, and a touch of spicy hops.  A little caramel and soap come out as the beer warms.  The mouthfeel is medium with medium carbonation and a short finish.  I really like this brew!  Its light enough to have a few but tasty enough to satisfy.

12 oz. bottle pours dark ruby, light tan head that fades quickly.  Great sweet molasses aroma as well as light roasted coffee.  Good rich sweetness, with a nice dry light roasted coffee bitterness and a chocolate aftertaste.  A little buttery mouthfeel with light carbonation but solidly drinkable.  Good example of the style.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark amber to brown with reddish highlights and one finger white tan head that settles quickly. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of yeast, grain, earth, light chocolate, some floral esters. Flavor is about the same, some very faint roast and slightly more chocolate, malt flavors. Medium body with a malty finish.
Brown, red color with a tan head. Aroma is very malty - fruity, roasted, coffee. Flavor is sweet but there is some bitterness and hops.
(12oz bottle). Pours a brown-red liquid with a caramel color head.  slight roasted coffee and caramel aroma.  Caramel flavor with burnt coffee flavor.  The finish is quite dry.

Pours a deep red color with a nice amount of lacing and a good thick head that lasts through the beer. Aroma is impressive and smells like hot wort. Taste is just as good and smooth through the finish. Enjoyable beer and one of the better bocks that i have encountered.

Pours very dark brown with a thick tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is of toast and sweet malts and hops.  Taste is sweet malt, dry hops and a slightly bitter hop aftertaste.  Good beer but not a "bock" at all.

Bottle. Poured dark reddish brown with a small off brown head that dissipated quick.  Smell composed mostly of grains and some herbs. Flavor was laid back and had a medium sweet tone, composed mostly of caramel, raisin, sugar, molasses and malts, but added a hop kick to keep it from being too sweet.  Medium body, nicely cut to find the balance between water and sap. Finished with light hop notes and slightly bitter.  A fine beer, that had a little more than most spring bocks offer.  Nicely brewed.

12oz bottle.   Over-carbonated and a touch thin in the mouth, though not thin is you think of it as a dunkel instead of bock.   Dark brown with a lasting beige head.   Lightly fruity aroma with a touch of strawberry, some caramel, cocoa, and dark bread crust.   The flavor is dry and a touch acidic, with a dark roasted and almost tart finish that has a toasty chocolate malt touch.   There is some almost burnt bread and berry up front, but just a modest sweetness.   This is some very attenuated stuff.   Hops are mild in flavor and are mostly just noticeable in a medium finishing bitterness that is accentuated by the dryness.   The aroma is initially interesting, but this one could benefit from some more body and malt flavor.

12-oz bottle. Coffee colored with pillowy tan persistent head. Good lacing on the glass. Aroma of tabacco, dried apricot, coffee and raisin. Taste is earthy and smoky with a hint of grassy sourness. Mellows into coffee grounds and a small amount of hoppy finish. Medium texture. I was disappointed with this beer. The taste did not match the promising aroma. But I am not very experienced with this style. I would try it again in a year and see if my thoughts about it change.

Bottle.  Pours deep dark amber with a 2 finger creamy light tan head that leaves very nice lacing.  The nose is caramel, light chocolate and dark fruits.  The taste is caramel malt, light spice, a touch of ashy cocoa, tobacco and some hops in the finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  Decent Bock.  I like how the hops cut some of the sweetness out that is usually associated with the style

12 ounce bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours clear burgundy with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is caramel with an earthiness (hops?) and that classic, immediately-identifiable Anchor breadiness. Flavor is very mellow with a nice bready sweetness, caramel, molasses, earth, creamy light mousse, and red fruits. Lots of notes here, body is thin but not watery enough to dilute the nice flavor profile. This has a lot more going on than other ubiquitous bocks (Im looking at you SN Glissade and Shiner). Liked it quite a bit.

Bottle. Poured a darker amber, brownish color with a nice two finger creamy white head. Aroma was cereal, fruits, and malts. Flavor was brown sugar, molasses, and malts. Not a bad beer. Very good actually. A great spring beer.

Bottle. Pours a deep cloudy dark brown body with a ruby hue and a big frothy tan head with little retention. Really interesting, complex aroma of herbs and spices, plums, syrupy, cloves, cough medicine. I kinda like it but dont really understand. Flavor has some sweet caramel, raisin, licorice. Medium bodied, somewhat lively, tingly mouthfeel. There is a bit of a dishsoap background. Overall really enjoyable.

~Carmel and biscuit malts in aroma, some raisin.
~Pours a dark clear reddish black brown with small brown head.
~Raisin, malty flavor, some bitterness, but not hoppy, good flavor, residual sweetness.
~med body, med CO2, sweet balanced finish.
~Great bock. Very enjoyable. Maybe my favorite bock.
12 oz bottle.   Pours brown with off white head.   A very nice malty, bready beer with some  caramel and a little nuttiness.   Enjoyable and could definitely drink more than one.
Dark brown with a creamy tan head. Caramel chocolate and mild banana aroma and taste with a nice creamy palate.
Bottle. Pours brown with a big white ice cream head. Flavor is caramel, toffee, dried fruit. Makes for a solid session beer.

12oz bottle served in a shaker pint. Poured a deep reddish brown with two fingers of tan head. For a minute I thought that I had the porter instead! Some caramel malt and a bit of hops in the aroma. Light to medium bodied. Fairly malty flavor with some chocolate malt. Bit of a hop bite. Not what I look for in a bock, but a very drinkable beer on a purely hedonistic lever. So I guess the lesson is dont categorize, just drink!
12 oz bottle. Pours a dark color, notes of red. Small tan head. Aroma is malty, hops, notes of dried fruits. Flavor is a nice balance of malts and hops, touches of fruit. A pretty good beer.

Dark slightly hazy mahogany with a little head that siappears quickly.   Smells of medium roast, ripe fruits, and sweet tarts.  Medium body, crisp but light to start, transitions to a little raisin sweetness, a bit of noble twang, and a little bitterness from the roast.  Not too much to it, finishes with just a bit of bitterness.   Decent, but nothing exciting.

From bottle. Malt and rich nose, with licorice, caramel, molasses and brown sugar. Mild neutral hop undertones. Sweet and fragrant malty character with no oxidation notes. Dark ruby-brown, almost black, clear with rich foamy light tan lacing head. Medium-heavy watery body, not quite oily, with medium carbonation and light acidic fizz. Starts surprisingly dry for the aroma. Actually quite a shock in some ways, as the really sweet notes in the nose made me expect a doppelbock sweetness. However, the sweet taste was not found, but rather a tart carbonic acid and fruity acidity is here, with mild astringency and hop bitterness. Smoky and burnt malt, and a soda water tang. Finish is dry with mild bitterness and light tang. After is dry with some chalkyness. A very odd taste to go with the aroma - not quite digging this balance.

The pour was dark molasses with go retention/lacing to tan frothy head. Aromas of molasses, caramel, burnt malts, light pine hops. Tasted of light spicy hops, burnt malts(caramel, light honey), light toffee. Slightly sweet, bitter, sour. Leaves a light burnt malt finish.

12oz bottle. Aroma: raisins, molasses, hints of chocolate, caramel toffee, slight vinous fruit, hints of almost savory roasted grain character, and soft alcohol. Appearance: deep dark brown and ruby red, brilliantly clear. Medium-sized tan head that fades to a persistent ring and leaves spots and short streaks of lace on the glass. Taste starts a little more watery than aroma would indicate. Starts bready and grainy, with very subtle hints of sour/acidic fruit, lots of fruit-cakey malts, some dry roasty malt flavors, and a mild malt sweetness. At mid-palate, light-to-moderate slightly earthy but mostly neutral hop bitterness balances the bready, toasty, molasses malt notes. Beer finishes moderate - neither dry nor full - with some malt sweetness and a grainy and slightly roasty aftertaste. Mouthfeel: full-bodied and slippery with growing creaminess as the suds swirl around the mouth. Carbonation is somewhat light, but provides a pleasant texture. Overall: a very decent brew with a complex malt character. But it doesnt taste like a Bock - not enough malt richness (melanoidins, caramel, sweetness) and a little too much roasted grain character. Still quite drinkable.

A very nice bock.  Rich coffee/caramel aroma with a hint of breadiness.  Nice lacing and chestnut color.  The taste is a little dry, not too sticky sweet.  Coffee, cocoa, some pecan cake.  Crisp mouthfeel for a beer this full bodied.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown cloudy pour with a thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, nuts and floral hops.  Full bodied taste, a beer you can literally almost chew.  Nice even flavor of roasted malt, almonds, dried fruit that finishes with a floral, herbal slightly bitter taste.  Nice brew.

Pours dark brown with ruby edges and a tan head. Aroma is rich malt, floral hop, and some roasty notes. Flavor is lightly roasty, some herbal hop, with a bitter finish. Reminds me a lot of the Christmas beer.

Dark dark brown with a thick tan head. Aroma is caramel malt, a little bit herbal. Very straightforward flavor, just great malt, and great hops. The balance is perfect too, the hops arent too strong, they just create a subtle herbal quality that rounds out the malt flavor perfectly. Very smooth and very drinkable.

Quite dark in body with ruby tinges and a medium size, light tan head. Toasted malt aroma that got better as it warmed. Dried fruit in the taste, rich, dry, liquorice and meaty with a light bitter finish. Quite like this drop although I probably couldnt drink too many at once. Reminds me a bit of there porter as well. A fairly dry bock.

Bottle, Beer Ritz, Leeds. Poured a dark ruby tinged brown colour with a small head. Aroma not bad, roasted sweet malts and citrus. Flavour was roast malty, not much sweetness. Drinkable enough but lacks any real balance. Pretty underwhelmed really.

Opaque Dark brown, with a good amount of head and moderate lacing,
big bouquet.  low-medium amount of carbonation.  Flavors of dark roasted malts and some coffee, light to medium hops in the finish.  Notes of chocolate, grains and maybe black licorice.  Overall a pretty good bock with 
some porter type qualities.  I would drink this again, before Id go for a porter most likely.
Brown pour, nice foamy head.  Toasted malt, caramel, and some light resin.  Flavor is a bit malty sweet but finishes with a really well balanced hop bite.  Nice brew.

pours out dark brown and thick with a tall frothy coffee colored head that was bubbly.  the body is dark and no light penetrated the body.  the aromas are toffee and roasted malts.  theres some caramel, and plum present.  its not bitter to the nose, but rather sweet.  it is light bodied and nicely carbonated and finishes pretty dry.  i taste caramel, sugar, some pepper, and lightly roasted malts.  its refreshing and has a nice aftertaste.  it doesnt linger to long and is plesent.

Bottle from Utobeer.  Very dark ruby, thin tan head.  Yes a little bocky on aroma, some fresh prune,  some jammy fruit.  Yes its a half decent beer, with a lot of dry malt in the mouth and on the swallow.  Some faint hop sting on the end.  Its fine.  Quite drinkable.

Resin and herbal aroma. Poured a gorgeous dark red color with great head retention. Excellent initial taste of citrus, floral, and hay. However, I dont like the lingering bitter after taste. I dont mind the hoppy after taste, but idk what I taste afterwards, perhaps I got a bad batch. Overall this is a good beer. Ill try another batch later on and adjust my score if need be.
POurs cola brown. Nose is earthy malts, sweet caramel and toffee. Flavor is very earthy, bready, floral, biscuity, sweet toasty malts.

Pours dark brown with a small dense tan head that leaves some stringy lace. Sweet and roasty caramel and toffee aroma. Similar flavor with a hint of dark fruit. Rich mouthfeel with light carbonation and a slightly bitter finish.

Poured cloudy and brown with reddish highlights.  A two-finger tall, off-white head appeared and offered average lacing.  The aroma was lots of malts, light toffee and slightly metallic.  The flavor was malts, toffee, unchecked alcohol and a touch of chocolate.  Almost medium in body.  Didnt quite come together for me.  The weird combination of metal and alcohol on the finish really distracted me.

Pours a dark reddish brown. Minor light brown head. Dark and murky but glassy on the exterior.

Heavy cherry sweet liqueur smell, like a barleywine. Roasted malt is nutty and also sweet; brown sugary. Some mild grape notes.

Harsh sweet cherry flavor mixed with burnt, nutty malt. Brown sugar with grainy barley. Molasses and corn syrup.

Feels syrupy and thick. Has a sharp little bite on the back of the tongue. Ashy and substantial. Good, but not great. Strong and sweetly roasted.
Pours Brown and more heavy than taste. Has an oaky chocalte bar taste.  Cramel scent and a hefty brew.  Had in a12 oz. bottle and poured in stein.  great beer for the changing seasons.

1.6 pint. Pours dark brown with thick cream head. Nose is Strong barley, caramel and some herbs.
Flavor Is very earthy taste. Nuts, barley, some Oak, caramel. some chocolate. Finish a little thin for a bock. but still pretty damn good.

Dark brown. A frothy, active head leaves a glass-coating but temporary lace. Aroma has plenty of caramel, which clashes a bit with some herbal tendencies in it. Flavor blends dusty earth, caramel, and nut into a pleasing harmony. A hint of chocolate. Slightly lactic. Medium body and carbonations. Slightly tannic. Would drink again.

Dark translucent brown. Aroma is a bit nutty with some caramel, malt and sweetness. Rich and full of chocolate malts, caramel and some fruit. A little thinner and drier than I expected, but pretty good.
A medium-bodied, amber brew with prunes and roasted malts on the nose. Its big character suggests cherries, raisins, hazelnut, and coffee with a sweet, hoppy finish and light mouthfeel.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Market Glen Allen, VA. Pours a clear reddish brown color witha large creamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Dark malty aroma with notes of raisin and caramel. Taste is leafy, slightly metallic hops, green apple, raisin and light maltiness. Medium bodied.
A brown beer with a big head. Aroma was nutty. The taste was nutty, almost creamy, very malty, very smooth with a slight tobacco taste at the end.
330mL Bottle. Pours dark with heavy head. Sweet and dark,. Decent fun beer to drink but very underwhelming as a bock.

This is my first Bock in a many years.  It is an Anchor beer product.  The head frothed over the glass.  The dark beer was full of flavor.  It was a pleasure to drink.  The beer was a deep dark brown with a sweet finish.
Bottle. A nearly black pour, with a tan head that has impressive lacing. Stewed fruits and molasses on the nose. Flavours of chocolate and stewed fruits. Well balanced. Delicious!
Bottle.  Darkish black beer with a very strong head.  The aroma is lightly roasted, and the flavour is mildly roasted and malty. Overall an average beer.
A dark dunkel.   Tastes like  a dopplebock mixed with a porter.  A beautiful creamy head with a dark amber brown body.  Earthy malts mixed with caramel, chocolate, and a lightly bitter coffee finish.
Pours a dark brown with a thick creamy head. Taste is roasted malt, dark fruit, noble earthy hop bitterness. Nice malt aroma with a hint of chocolate. A solid brew.

12oz bottle from Orland Park Binnys single rack. Pours dark reddish brown with thick tan head. Aroma is sweet malt, caramel, and some citrus. Flavor is malty with caramel, chocolate, dark fruits and hint of citrus. Thick and chewy mouthfeel. Nice session beer to sit around a fire with.
Bottle. Chocolate, coffee and other roasted tones dominates the aroma aswell as the taste. Both are accompanied by fresh american hops. This is a very porteresque beer.

Pours dark amber with a good sized frothy tan head that leaves nice lacing.  Sweet malt aroma, bread with a hint of cinnamon.  Light bodied beer with a malt flavor and enough hops to compliment.  Mild bitter coffee finish.  Flavor and palate dont quite live up to the appearance and aroma but a good beer nonetheless.

Black with a tall tan head. Sweet dark malt aroma with strong liquorice, and some caramel. Ale-like fruitiness, with aromatic hops. Nice, though not at all a traditional bock aroma. Flavors of liquorice, burnt coffee, citrus hops. Rather like a hoppy porter. Ok, with enjoyable hops. Strange and different, though it got less enjoyable as I went on.
Bottle at a restaurant in Malmo, 19th May 09. Aroma of candy sugar and orange zest. Deep reddish tinted brown. Surprisingly light palate given the aroma. Sweet and malty on the tongue.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2011 Bottle, Rehills, Newcastle. A rich, spicy aroma and taste. Chocolatey taste reminiscent of their Porter, but without the long, lingering smack. The vineous aroma creeps in midway. Has plenty of fruit and hops, plus the distinguishing floral/grassy aromas their pale beers have. Truly an Anchor brew. Additional notes, having had the draft version (Free Trade Inn, Newcastle) - very old ale-like, I did think of Marstons Owd Rodger in its heyday, at first! Definitely tastes more than 5.5%, vineous, rich and quite excellent.
Bottle. Caramelly coffee chocolate aroma. Very roasty. Somewhat thin palate for a supposed bock. Mocha sweet flavor.

Beautiful very dark brown with a shapely head that built and crowned over the rim of the glass and kept its retention between pours so the second pouring resulted in a kind of pyramid look to the head.  Excellent.  Clean chocolate aroma,  Gritty texture to the roast, chewy but not quite thick.  It strikes me as traditional from each angle but still captures me as unique as a whole.  Maybe thats because there arent many good west coast bocks.  Great beer.

330ml bottle from Beers of Europe. A tasty malty  beer. Nicely done - good flavours, firm, but not too assertive or extreme. This is not an adventurous beer, but it does what it does very well, and is an enjoyable and satisfying brew. Rather low in strength for a Bock of any description, and I suspect the name Bock is used more for the association with Spring than for the strength. I quite like Anchor beers - they are not exciting, adventurous or wonderfully tasty, but they are decent, well made beers.

Bottle.  Very dark brown with a beige foam.  Aromas are earthy light roast malts with lots of herbal notes.  Winter berry fruits with dark chocolate.  Flavours are sweet toffee and chocolate malts with gritty coffee.  Smoky with raisins and berries.  Good.

Really enjoyed the mellow style of this beer.   Smells of butter, caramel, and soft malts come out.  Flavor is butter, molasses cake and heavy on the malts.  Great looking beer, a peerless brown with a tiny bubbled soft carbonation that adds to the pleasant flavors.  Thanks Anchor.  2009 12 oz.

Amber-brown pour producing a thick, tan head and heavy lacing. Toffee and raisin on the nose with a touch of tobacco and coffee. Slick feel coupled by a creamy, malty body. Caramel, molasses and plum flavors backed by multi-grain bread and chocolate pudding. Nice bock, good standard.

This beer has a great malt profile with a good chocolate note. Hop bitterness balances it out and makes it very drinkable. Nice smooth mouthfeel. Solid malt aroma. I will definitely be purchasing more.
poursdark red with some ruby highlights with a small tan head.  Slight hop hitterness.  ok

From the bottle.  It is really a struggle to figure out what to knock about this beer.  Looks good, tastes good; strong in the areas you want a bock to be strong in.  Could be a bit heavier, I suppose, and when accidentally served in a frosty mug, the head tends to break up in an unattractive manner.  Otherwise, a very fine beer.

Malty caramel and molasses nose. Clear very dark mahogany brown with small off-white head. Caramelized sugar maltiness in flavor with light earthy spicy hops to back. Finish is relatively dry and roasty with some chocolate hints. Pretty tasty.

Im glad to see more Anchor beers making their way to Florida. This one pours a deep, dark crimson color with a dull, glowing translucency. A tall column of beige foam is quick to dissipate, leaving wet flares of lacing to break apart and dry as hard spots. The nose is inviting, dark, malty, fruity underpinnings being accompanied by hints of cocoa, nutmeg, clove and orange peel. Fig and raisin comprise the bulk of the sweetness. Flavors follow suit, but delve even deeper. Traces of coffee and tobacco join the fig, raisin, and spice, with zesty orange peel and cocoa working nicely within the mix. Medium bodied, smooth, and highly drinkable, the finish features concentrated cocoa and woody, earthy spice. You can definitely sense the Anchor bloodlines in this one, with traces of OSA and Porter showing well. Damn nice small bock here.
I was expecting a bit more. Pretty light but overall has some good balanced flavors. Some light caramel malt and a hint of earthy hops.

(Bottle)  Wow.  This beer got my attention with the first sip...and I cant say I even like this style normally.  Bocks can be terribly boring, but this one grabs you and takes you on an exciting ride!  A rich, dark aroma, almost like worcestershire sauce, emanates from this brew.  Normally, that kind of aroma signals a poorly-executed beer, usually one that is too sour.  But there is barely any sourness in the flavour!  And it is also, thankfully, not too sweet or too heavy!  There is a fair amount of alcohol in the aroma, which I normally dont like, but in the case of this beer it blends well with the other things going on.  Theres a rich maltiness...and a very dry aftertaste.  Overall, it is quite smooth, yet complex.  Outstanding!

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2009 belied by its opacity and sturdy head, the nose is not of roast but of sweet cereal malts. flavor is however first and foremost extremely bitter, with a definite smoked end. im not sure which of the two i enjoy more, they are a stellar combination of this dynamic palate. mouthfeel borders on dry. stunning beer!
Pours a dark brown color with a thick creamy head. A very bitter smell with a smooth crisp taste slightly malty with a hop aftertaste. A good beer but not one of anchors best.

Thick blackish pour, massive head and lace, yum. Hoppy, dry aroma. Nutty malt dominates, with some corny bitter hops. Roasted caramel in there. A little bit watery and not as much kick as I expect from a bock. Dissappointing effort from Anchor.
Pours a rich brown with a thick creamy head.  Aroma is slightly bitter, taste is complex, with hints of hops and chocolate.  Excellent.

12 oz bottle from Canals Hainesport. Pours a very good looking deep red/brown with a large creamy beige head that leaves a nice pool of floating creamy bubbles and lots of lace. Initial aroma is sweet and of dark fruits, raisins and fig, chocolate and upon warming some floral notes emerge. Medium bodied with lively carbonation and a quickly fading aftertaste. Flavors of chocolate, grains, dark fruits and slight dates. Solid offering from Anchor.

Pours dark reddish-brown with minimal head.  Very sweet raisin aroma with a hint of chocolate.  A nice balanced malt flavor with bitterness at the end.  Nothing bad to really say about this one, it was a pleasant surprise.  Anchor brewing company continues to impress me with their solid offerings.

Nice dark color to this one.  Smells of malts and raisins.  Taste is a little complex.  Not that carbonated at all.  Has flavors of malts and a very bitter fruits.  Has a very bitter aftertaste in the end.  But overall, not too bad of a brew.

The bottle pours a dark brown/chestnut color with a small, but solid tan head.  Nice lacing along the side of the glass.   The beer has a distinct aroma of malt and rye.  Flavor includes roasted malts, more of the rye notes, with hints of dates and raisins.  Theres slight hop bitterness in the finish.  This is a tasty, solid offering from the folks at Anchor.  I highly recommend taking a tour of the brewery if you are ever in San Francisco, very cool tour!

Ft. Myers, Fl. - Total Wines - 12 oz bottle. Finally found this elusive brew from Anchor - one of the only ones I am missing. Very dark brown - almost black pour with a decent sized mocha colored head. Pleasant wort-like aroma with some dates and raisin notes. Good, solid rib-sticking bock flavor with brief hints of licorice, raisins, baked brown bread and a brief hint of chocolate. Thickish mouthfeel for a bock Solid, as expected.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a red hue and a quickly receding head. The aroma is soy and bitter hops. Light hop taste, with wheat, salt and pretzels as well.
On tap at Mahars. Pours a nice brown color with little head. Flavor is sweet and nutty, but watery, still good though.

12oz bottle-pours a rich light brown head and mahogany color.  Aroma is roasty-dark malt, pine hops fades in and out.  As it warms molasses too.  Taste is ashy-dark malt, earthy hops.  As it warms the ashy is replaced by chocolate which improves the taste.  Thanks jwc215 for picking this out.
Poured reddish dark brown, nutty, roasted malts, bready, molasses, caramel, little dark fruits, slight hops.

12oz in mug.  Deep brown with medium tan head.  Mild raisiny and roasty nose with a touch of sulfur.  Flavor is reminiscent of overextracted coffee, rather astringent and puckering.  I admit, this is not my favorite style, but I was really hoping for a big toasty, Munich-y wallop.

Say, this is a tasty surprise.  Pours darker than expected from looking at the bottle.  Dark brown pour with tan head.  Great lacing.  Really a pretty beer.  Im probably rating this a bit high, but this hit the spot and is the kind of beer Ive been looking for... rich and flavorful but light on the ABV.  Nice dark malts, chocolate notes, some dark fruits, but a snappy little hop presence, too.  I bought a single, but Ill be going back for a sixer.  Nice.

pours dark brown with light mocha head.
Aroma is hoppy and pine, some light raisins and nice bready sweetness as well as other dark fruits. Really impressed by it.
Taste, hoppy more on floral side, malty some lingering bitterness in the finish and spices. Darkf ruits, light caramel.
Could certainly get better with age and lose some of the bitter side.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2009 Sweet raisins and molasses with some slight chocolate notes.  Blackish brown, slight and deep red hue, medium tan head.  Bitter chocolate and cold coffee flavors, not well-balanced.  Big carbonation, slight thinness, fairly clean finish.  Not super impressed with this beer.  Seemed more like a soulless Stout than a Bock.

2009 Bottle - Pours dk brown with a small, ashy tan head...aroma is dark malt, molassas, old fruit...flavour is a bit astringent at first, and continues into a thin and dry minerally chocolate brew, roasty...finish is dry caramel...decent bock...
22 oz.  Reddish-brown pour with a thick brown head. Sweet aroma of malt. Aftertaste is slight sweetness that seemed to linger longer as the beer warmed up.

bottle..ruddy brown pour,thin off white head no lacing . sweet caramel and dark fruit aromas.roasted malt flavors with hints of tobacco,chocolate and cinnamon. a touch metallic and thin .finishes dry and a little bitter .

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark borwn and hazy with a small tan head. Sweet yet roasted malt and ense pinewood hoppy aroma. Light acidic, overripe fruity and somewhat wooden in initial flavour. Somewhat wineous and dense malty in base flavour. Lasting malty and wineous impression into the finish.

Bottle.  Poured into a snifter dark brown with a pearly carbonated brown head.  Rich aroma of sweet raspberries, chocolate, raisins and caramel malt.  Flavor was a dry roasted component not present in the nose.  It is also far more watery than the nose indicates.  Starts with some minerals and dry roasts, and finishes with semisweet chocolate, metal and water.  Palate is quite thin and carbonated, finishing with dryness.  What a let down past the aroma, let it warm to just below cellar temp for best results
Bottle from Total Wine in Roseville, CA.  This one was indeed strong with some odd flavor combos.  It was definitely infused with spice and an odd sour mix of tobacco and fruit.  Weird one.

Very dark pour, where some light sneaks through. A big, off white head the reduces down to a slight film. Aroma is tobacco, cinamon, roast, spice. Stronger than most other dunklers. Flavor is spciey and dry, with lots of cinamon and tobacco. This is an excellent beer

Had this one at Manhattans in the Old City.

Black. Medium head. Aroma:  Roasted malt blend. Flavor: Roasted Chocolate malt, herbs, sweet. Roasted malt finish.

Pours deep mahogany into a Shaker.  Fluffy off-white micro head tophats the rim and holds excellent retention. Toasty malts and sweet grass aromas.  Dark caramel upfront and a little thin.  Crisp, dry and lasting roasted malt finish.

Bottle.  Sweet caramel malt aroma, with fruit.  Deep brown body, small tan head.  Super flavor of malt, appropriate sweetness, molasses.  Very lengthy, though subtle, finish, that lingers on the tongue.  Wonderful beer.

Bottle...  poured deep ruby with a nice beige head, nice lacing.  Fruity aroma with also sweet, cocoa malts.  Full, creamy palate with flavors of toasty malts, pistachios, fruit and a little floral presence from some hops in the finish.
Pretty typical bock here but nothing extraordinary about it. One of many examples very similar to each other in my opinion.

Bottle.  Pours very dark with a faint ruby hue.  Tan foamy head.  Earthy aroma with hint of banana.  Flavor starts with a hint of coffee and roasted malts, followed by a slight flowery sweetness and a estery/cascade hop finish.  A very good bock.
clearish, slight fog, dark red / brown color with a thin off white head, big malty caramel nose, roasty hop bitter flavor, most body of any anchor brews ive tried, piney, clove, dark roast caramel
Dark brown color with attractive garnet highlights.  Strong malty aroma and lightly toasted flavor of sweet malt.  The medium body beer lingers with some alcohol warmth.

330 mL. Pours a dark, clear brown with a good two-finger, off-white head with good retention. Aromas of milk chocolate, roasted malt, raisins. Taste is slightly thin and highly carbonated but there is a lot of caramel, burnt sugar, and dark fruits. Balancing hops shine through in the finish. A good session beer.

I cant believe i havent tried this beer yet, Purchased recently on sale for 5.99 a sixer: Pours a dark reddish brown with a medium sized tan head. Aroma is very pleasent and enticing with its lightly roasted malt character, pecans and milk chocolate. Mouthfeel is so soft and creamy- its a completely differnt taste from what im used to in bocks. Flavors are sort of milk chocolatey and coffee notes.
Pours dark brown, with a thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted caramel malt.  Taste is of roasted malts.  Very good beer, I really enjoyed it.

Draft at the local tonight with dinner.  appearance number is somewhat skewed since it arrived in my ceramic mug from the mug club.  The head was nice and foamy though.  I was expecting a bit more nuttiness in the nose but recieved a fair portion of caramel.  Body is full and rich.  Chocolate malts with a sprinkling of instant hot chocolate greet the tounge and surround it with plentiful indulgance.  A crisp dry finish offsets the buffalo chicken sangwich nicely.
Poured a dark brown, almost like a porter, with a tan head.  Seemed somewhat thin. Heavy malt notes throughout.  mostly dark cocoa and some bread notes.  A nice dryness throughout.  Good.

Dark brown/ruby red color, thick off-white head.  The aroma is incredible, a mix of dark fruits, cherries, chocolate, and sweet malt.  The flavor is roughly the same as the aroma, a nice mixture of dark fruits and chocolate.  The finish is sweet, but is then balanced by a slight hoppyness.  Excellent bock overall.

Bottle.  Poured a dark red with a three finger brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and fruit.  Flavor is cherries, with a chocolate and coffee finishing.  Somewhat light body with mild carbonation.

Bottle thanks to mmm///beer. Pours a beautiful dark red color with a large brown head. There is lots of brown in the body, mixed with the redness it almost seems like purple. The aroma is great; sweet berries, chocolates, toasted malts, and some sweeter candy notes. The flavor is very complex and nice; tons of fruit upfront, sour cherries, strawberry and others. A rich chocolate and brown sugar follow, and some light coffee in the finish. Light body and a somewhat easygoing beer. Very nice.

This reddish-brown ale poured with a decent tan head and a malty aroma. The flavor is caramel malt with a bit of smokiness and carbonation. This is a well-crafted session beer for those who enjoy a dark one.

Pours very dark ruby brown with a thick and creamy finger of tan head that lingered.  Aroma is mostly chocolate and lightly roasted malts.  Body is smooth and lets through a very sweet beer that again is chocolatey with some prune undertones and a slight hop and roasted malt bitterness for balance.

12 oz. bottle poured into tumbler- poured very dark brown with red tints when held to a light source, high carbonation, tan head 3 mm thick was defiant and refused to bubble away.  Aroma of caramel, malt, and prunes.  Hits the mouth with a medium body, malt is tasty and stands alone well, a touch of sweetness in the middle, finish has crisp finish with hops underneath.  Sorry Shiner, this is my sessioner for awhile...

A dunkler bock?  Guess that’s why it’s so dark.  Nice dense off-white head.  Caramal nose.  Not quite as malty as I would have expected.  Hops dry this beer out, tastes a bit of oxidation?  Not diggin’ the aftertaste.  I’d expect a cleaner brew from Anchor.

Had this in the bottle at Frankie’s music club in Toledo, OH. It poured a dark brown with brownish head. I am not the biggest bock fan, but it was the only decent sounding beer they had there.. and it actually wasnt that bad. Lots of dark malty goodness with some smokey finish. Very good stuff! Cheers!
bottle, dark brown color with dirty head, nose of malts and sugar, sweet caramel flavors and some plums, roasted malt finish

Big 700ml "Anchor" bottle.  Dark brown, light tan creamy head.  Aroma is of a very bold, rich malts.  Big dark carmels and toffee notes.  Flavor has a very bold toast.  Rich malt flavor character.  Crisp hop balance.  Very balanced.  It is an alcoholic version of a latin malta drink.  Rich and nutritious!  My new favorite Anchor, sorry Liberty.

12 oz. Nearly opaque chocolate with ruby tints. Three finger head settles to a creamy half-inch. Earth-spiced chocolate and caramel-covered raisins in the nose. Maybe some juniper? Flavor is the same as their Christmas Ale except thinner and maybe slightly drier. Piquant-spicy juniper, chocolate-covered blackberry, dates, caramel, more earthy spices (anise?) and some resin. Medium-heavy body is watery, lightly carbonated and finishes almost astringently dry. Doesnt taste like any other Bock Ive tried except maybe the exceptional Doppel/Weizenbocks.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2008 12 oz. bottle. Pours a very dark brown almost black color with a thick frothy tan head. The aroma is a punget roasted malt with black licorice and raisin. Good sticky lacing on the glass. The taste is roasted malt and dark chocolate with a sweet finish. A very good dunkle from Anchor

THOUGHTS: I never saw this one before. I used to shy away from Anchor, but recently found out how great their beers can be. This is no exception. A great beer, but probably even better in cooler weather.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured an extremely dark brownish red. It looked brown until held to the light, where it glowed red with an average-sized, kind of creamy, light tan head that mostly lasted and left excellent and thick lacing. The aroma was moderate to heavy roasted and burnt malt, light herbal hops, soy sauce, spices, a little dark fruit and light milk chocolate malt. The initial flavor was lightly sweet, acidic and bitter; while the finish was light to moderately sweet and bitter, lightly acidic and then sour right at the end with an average duration. There was tons of roasted and burnt malts with a hint of coffee and a little tiny bit of dar, sour fruit. Some soy sauce too. The medium to full body was creamy with somewhat soft carbonation and a moderate to heavy astringent finish.

Pours very dark brown with a ruby head and a big lasting pillowy tan head. Sweet malty caramel aroma, but somewhat faint. Similar caramel flavor with dry roasted coffee, nut and chocolate malt flavors in the background. Nice malty beer.
Average label, dark pour, foamy head.  Fresh, garden hop aroma.  Smooth and hoppy on the palate.  Medium-rich hops and malts.  It has some kick, but is mostly well-mannered.
Coke color,small loose beige head. Rich malt nose.Sweet but watery malt start light dry roast finish. Lacks body. Good lacing
Quite caramely and nutty in the aroma and flavor, also nutty in flavor akin to a hazelnut brown ale, malted-up flavor but thin, somewhat watery palate.  Its a straight 7/10 beer.

Pours very dark with a reddish tinge, beige head. Caramel with burnt chocolate in the nose. Sweet malt with dark chocolate and an almost burnt roasted flavor. Finishes with a hoppiness that was suprising
Poured pitch black with a thick tan head. Aroma - roast malt. Flavor was quite sweet with notes of roast malt and dark fruit. Taste of liquorice or possible anise was dominant and for me off putting.

12oz bottle(courtesy of RSRIZZO)-Pours dary ruby brown with a nice loose tan head and an aroma of Roasted malt, caramel, and toffee. Taste is of the same with some coffee and a little chocolate. This full bodied brew is pretty good even though I am not fond of this style.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 pours black, with tight brown head and lots of lacing with aromas of coffee and chocolate,taste of the same but reminds me of drinking a port, full body very malty just a great beer
Smells very malty and tastes roasted.  I guess im just not into Bocks...  Its probably pretty good if youve aquired the taste.

Roasted chocolaty malt.  Cheese and cream cheese lactose aroma.  Dark cola coloration. Caramel flavor with bitter roasted flavor.  Coffee flavors with bitter roasted flavor and some earthy root.  Mild palate, light bitter duration.  Somewhat chewy.  Good duration.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2008 Pours a dark reddish-brown with a large creamy tan head that shrinks to a thin cap..
Aroma is sweet toasty malt, some molasses and toffee. A little light coffee.
Toffee nutty malt flavour. Light coffee and dark fruit bitterness.

bottle. pours dark ruby with beige head. aroma of toasted malts, licorice, toffee, and smoke. flavors are sweet licorice and dark fruit, very subtle chocolate and smoke. med body. not really into this one.

Deep ruby/brown with a towering, thick, beige head.  Caramel, fruity, malty, toffee, and a bit nutty aroma.  Body is a little thiner than I expected.  Was hoping for a little more intense flavor, but its good regardless.  Nutty, toffee, caramel, malts, and a little fruit.  A very drinkable bock, and isnt that the only thing that matters?

Deep brown appearance with a medium size, long lasting tan head and little lacing.  Sweet, malty aroma with nuances of molassass, dark fruit and caramel.  Taste is sweet as well.  Caramel, toffee and fruit in the forefront;  earthy, nutty flavors follow.  Rich, medium-to-full bodied, decently carbonated mouthfeel.  Lingering finish.

Pours a very dark reddish brown. Nice fluffy  beige head. Aroma is very sweet roasted caramel and chocolate malt. Flavor is very robust and sweet. Very caramel with some vanilla and honey notes. There seems to be a tiny bit of fruitiness in the finish as well. Medium-full body and a nice thick mouth feel. Very nice all around

12oz. Bottle:  Malty aroma with scents of caramel, a little fruitiness, and some nuts.  Poured dark brown/dark red/dark purple in color with a medium-sized, creamy, rocky, beige head that shrank but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Lightly sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet.  Tastes very malty with notes of nuts, wood, honey, grains, and a hint of dark ripe fruits.  Medium to full body.  Thick, creamy texture.  Average carbonation.  Sweet, malty finish.
aroma is of sweet alcohol and hints of malty caramel.  pours almost black with a thick creamy tan head.  flavor is nutty, bready and grainy with some hops and sourness.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2008 Pours dark brown almost black with a good sized tan head. Plenty of tan lacings. Aroma is of roasted malts. Taste is mild soy and molasses, nice amount of bitter hops. Well balanced brew.  Not one I will drink daily but very enjoyable as a change of pace. Good job Anchor!

12 oz. single bottle from Total Wine.  Pours a  dark brown color with a light tan head.  Aroma is sweet malts with a bit hops and some fruity notes.  Taste is nutty, roasted malt and a light hopped finish.  Easy to drink and very tasty, I will grab a six pack of this the next time I see it.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2008 Bottle. Pours dark brown with a moderately large brown head. Aroma is sweet malt---bread and dark fruits predominating---with some herbal hops. Flavor is bready, nutty, a little roast, a little grain, possibly a sour note, and a short finish with a few hops. A bit unusual, with crisp, almost sharp malt instead of the usual bock malt character. Pretty good though.

Attractive tawny garnet body with a tight slightly oily tan head.  Bread, gain, cream, and plums with an undercurrent of dark green herbal hops.  Mouthfeel is a little on the bright side, was hoping for a tad more thickness.  Brassy grains, raisins, coco powder, and toasted biscuit.  Finishes with a bit of malted milk and is gone.
12oz bottle. very dark with amber highlights, fluffy brown head. aroma of hops and malt. slightly bitter first taste. smooth dry finish, nutty. nice beer

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a very dark brown color with ruby highlights and a a very large brown head. The aroma was sweet, malty and lightly roasty. The flavor was tangy, bitter, roasty and a but nutty with a long tangy an d roasty finish. The mouthfeel was decently thick. Decent but rather forgettable.

A nice looking beer when poured into a mug. A great head that sticks around with a beautiful mahogany body. One of the nicer looking bocks and beers I have seen. The aroma is full of nuts and you even pull a bitter aroma if that is possible, you get a good sense of what is coming. The first taste is bitter and nutty. Nice but it sits a little off on the palate. As is usual with me it betters as it warms. I may just start drinking everything at room temperature to start.

Opaque dark brown pour with a three-quarter inch tan head. Nutty aroma with some toasted malt. Flavor is dark: lightly bitter nut, maybe toasted pecan, wood and black bread. Pleasantly smooth bock with medium thickness and a slightly slick mouthfeel. Rich and excellent.
Bottle.  Had this on draft in california when i was out there june 06.  Pours rich dark brown lather.  Notes of chocolate, hops, caramel and etoh.  decent.

nice dark brown pour with a small tan head that sticks to the edges. really malty aroma with dark raisins, molasses and cola. the flavor unfortunately cant live up to the aromas hype... malt, molasses, banana-like aftertaste and a bit of smokiness are followed up by a sourness and acidic finish that is really out of place. its not roasted astringency. its just plain sour. medium body with creamy carbonation which does give it a pleasant mouth feel.

Dark brown-amber with a moderate amount of tan foam. Fairly high viscosity for a bock. Definitely not a stereotypical bock! It tasted like stout/porter/bock hybrid. The aroma and taste is dominated by floral hops and roasted malt with a more faint caramel malt hiding in the background. Fairly dry bitter finish for a bock. An interesting but not spectacular experiment.

bottle poured into a snifter has a dark brown bordering on black color and a thick tan head that fell to a ring in the glass. aroma has malt, plumb, prune, caramel, and light alcohol. flavor has dark fruit and malt, with some raisin sweetness and bitters. looking at the description of this style it fits it well with burnt notes and nutty flavor. medium mouth feel with plenty of carbonation and finishes with hints of sweetness and drying.  really warmed to this as it went down.

Well, this beer smells great.  I thought I was in for a treat when I caught aroma of it.  Roasted malts and some sweet caramel.  It looks nice too.  Nice dark body with a thin, bubbly head around the edge of the glass.  Then, you drink it, and its just not good at all.  It finishes slight acidic and is slightly astringent.  It doesnt have much body, and falls flat.  Meh.

Aroma: chocolate, caramel, alcohol, and mgoy is right, there is some weird vinegar in there. And yep, flavor is malty, yet sour-astringent. Some crisp bitterness as well. Finishes with bitter chocolate.
Anchor Bock is a very dark mahogany beer with a nice but smaller head. The aroma a bit strange with some notes of vinegar. The flavor is a bit sour with a sour-malty finish.

Thick frothy biege head,carbonation good,dark brown to black opaque colour.Aroma,liccorice,caramel,molasses,malt.Flavo is strong but good,nice malt,caramel and liccorice sweetness.Finish bitter malty.

Well its certainly better than Shiner. Ahem, Pours quite dark brown in the glass, with a decent lighter brown head, that leads into some nice lacing.  The malt backbone is substantially lacking in this beer, but it does have a nice bit of spicy bitterness in the finish.

After being unimpressed with my first couple sips, I soon found this to be excellent.  It is almost opaque black, rather like a darker porter, with a fairly big, long-lasting dark tan head that slowly shrinks, never vanishes, and leaves very nice lacing.  The aroma is alcoholic burtn caramel, toast, a hint of chocolate, caramelized prunes and other fruit.  It is reminiscent of a milk or oatmeal stout but not quite as heavy.  The taste is similar, with the same elements as above.  It starts off rather dry with a light bitterness and faint sourness but becomes more full-bodied with a nice sweetness coming after a few sips.  It has a light peppery quality in the finish, along with the toast, burnt caramel, fruit.  The chocolate quality is exceedingly faint but, just barely, noticeable.  It is exceedingly smooth and drinkable.
Very good.  Dark pour with minimal head.  Aroma of roasted malt.  Taste is roasted with a small amt of hops bitterness.
4.05.08  Had this with Japanese food.  Possibly not the best combo?  Still good anyway.  Probably will go pick up a 6 of this one.  Try it.
This is quite good, and bold, yet I wonder if a bock is really the best choice for a spring seasonal.  Something lighter perhaps is appropriate.  Good bock though.
Bottle.  Came across as a little thin and low in flavor intensity.  Could use a little more malt backbone to stand up with the top bocks out there.  Disappointing.

First impression is that this is a pretty flawless example of the style.  Big flavors all over the mouth of roasty, nutty malt and crisp noble hops.  Spicy and herbal, while being rustic and earthy.  Bitterness does twinkle around in the back, but its a very balanced beer.  Palate is full and smooth.  the more i drink the more the malt starts to fade and the hops come out srtonger.  A little bit of a fruity/herbal flavor in there as well, like an apple or cherry.  Very nice beer.

Disappointed with this one.  The packaging made me expect a maibock but what poured out of the bottle tasted like porter.  Strong diacetyl and roasted notes.  Unlike any bock Ive ever had.  Still a good beer, just not to style.

courtesy of oteyj. nice 2 finger head, beige in coloration- beer itself is very dark brown with red. aroma is very nice; caramel, nuts, malt, cream, and marshmallows. first hit to the tongue is wondrous, great bock flavor w/ caramel, and some dark spices. somewhat watery, but a very solid beer overall.

Pours extremely dark brown with reddish tint. Nice beige two finger head and copious lacing Aroma of caramel and chocolate with hints of cream and, marshmallows. Flavor was caramel malt and a hint of hops and alcohol. Not complex by any means, but very smooth and tastey. A bit watery on the mouthfeel, but rich enough.

The Dan Journal #162.  Tasted 4/5/08.  12oz bottle.  Murky brown hue.  Spiraling bone white head.  Big nose!  Aromas of graham crackers and sugary dark fruit.  Medium bodied and very sweet.  Very rich.  Cocoa and fudge flavors with a mix of tart fruit.  A little too sweet and acidic.
A tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee. Rich full flavor that hits right away. And leaves no aftertaste.a good beer.

Hazy reddish-brown with a medium slowly diminishing tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, brown sugar and a hint of smoke.  Tastes of sweet caramel malt.  Medium palate with a light bitter and semi-dry finish.  Decent bock.

Thanks to Odeed for this one.  Pretty common beer, but Ive been interested in this for awhile.  If nothing else, than to try a bock made from whole hops.  Poor head and a very bland aroma.  I can tell this is has aged quite a bit.  Taste was on the thin side with notes of oxidation and a very reduced hop profile.  Still had that Anchor signature hop flavour to it.  Some decent toasted specialty malts saved this for me.

Pours a mahogony color with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet of dark fruits, toffee, caramel malts, and a hint of chocolate.  Flavor begins sweet with the toffee, caramel, and dark fruits.  Finishes with a little chocolate and floral hops.  Not too bad.
An amber beer with a small head, a strikingly sweet Aroma, Perfectly Balanced bitterness, Full of Malt flavor which ends on a slightly sweet note.

(Bottle from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/massachusetts/w target=blank>Julios Liquors) Pours dark iced-tea brown with some ruby/amber highlights. Very tall khaki head in my willibecher. Aroma of crystallized caramel with light chocolate/cocoa and perhaps licorice or molasses. Mouthfeel is smooth, medium-full but slightly loose. Flavor is light bittersweet chocolate/cocoa accompanied by a tea-like flavor. Light-medium bitterness overlays transitioning to a tea-like bitterness through finish. Tea-like quality is reminiscent of Anchor OSA 03 which was a great beer. This is a good beer although could be a little more malt-heavy.
Good beer. Poured a dark brown/ruby translucent color with tan head. Aroma of malt and fruit. Taste of dark roast malt and citrus. Medium carbonation and medium mouth feel. Good beer

Pours from the bottle dark brown with a nice thick tan head that dissipates slowly.  Aroma is heavy of caramel and very sweet to the nose.  Flavor starts off of caramel, raisin, a little bit of a dark chocolate bite and finishes sweet with a coffee undertone and dry.  Medium body with some fine carbonation to really hold the flavor for a little bit.  Good beer to curl up with after work.

Deep brown coloured body with a nice frothy tan head. Aroma of toasted malt, coffee, nuts and a bit of concord grapes. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong roasty malt flavour with some caramel sweetness and a faint bit of metal. Aftertaste shows some malt, nuts, fresh hops and a tiny bit of yeast. Overall, a good beer - not the best bock Ive had, but a decent offering from the brewery. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased at a small convenience store off Columbus Avenue in San Francisco, California on 30-March-2008.

Bottle. Pours deep clear brown with tan head. Aroma is rich caramel with a background of floral hops and a light citrus tang. Flavor is lightly sweet, roasted flavor, very subtle tartness, mild bitterness in the finish. Lively, moderately full palate.
bottle. quite dark for most bocks with a nice tan head and flavors of bitter chocolate and dark malt. nice finish because of hops. tasy bock.

bottle. Very little faint odor of molasses but a great dark amber color.  Little head but too noticeable carbonation when drinking.  Some licorice and port wine flavor.  Very dry and a lingering sweetness.  Possibly nice for the style but a little dry for my taste.

This is HORRIBLE!!!  Impressive visually but you cant drink a picture.  1/2 inch beige head sits above a rich reddish-brown brew.  The lacing is perfect; dense splashes of suds cling to the glass every 1/4 inch.  The aroma is an indistinguishable sweet...and the flavor is raw nuts and grain.  Not good...did everyone else try a different beer than me???
Dark brown color with a medium head.  Dry grainy aroma.  Strong rye, malt, grain and chocolate taste.  Oddly dry finish for a bock, but its pulled off well.

Bottle, nice sweet aromas plenty  of raisin and currant, a touch of roast. Nice taste a bit of metallic hops, slight cloying sweetness. Quite nice, drinkable but still satisfying as a darker brew. Sweet cream and coffee make this a pleasure to drink.

12 oz bottle from Crown Liquors.  Dark brown with a light tan head.  Aroma is alot of caramel and some dark fruit, plums and figs.  Taste is dark fruit, caramel and some metallic hops in the finish.  not too bad.

Pours a dark brown. Very dark brown in fact, when held to the light none passes through. If the light or glass are tilted some hues of ruby show through. The head is toasted white and large, thick and rich. Aroma is strong malt and west coast hops. Taste is also very malty, milk chocolate, drying anise, sweet and tart grapes, and dark roasted coffee in the finish. The mouth feel is pleasantly accurate, frothy and delicious. I believe the alcohol level is just right. Well done!

Poured a deep dark brown color with decent head that dissipated rapidly.  Aroma is sweet maltiness with notes of chocolate and dark fruits.  Taste has notes of dark fruit, chocolate, and roasted nuttiness.  Fairly complex.  Mouthfeel is pleasant and drinkability is fairly high.

Bottle. Pours dark brown ruby, off white head. Aroma is molasses, malt, salted nuts, anise. Flavor is the same with caramel and bread and is refreshing. The aroma is heavier than the flavor but I dont find the body to be too weak.

bottle - Pours dark amber with a big, light tan head.  The aroma is of caramel malt and dark fruit.  The roast caramel malt flavor has more hops than usual for this style and finishes dry.  I found it a little on the watery side.  Its alright as a session brew, but be aware that its not as sweet and dry as youd expect for the style and that there are certainly better bocks to be had.

Bottle: Brown with a nice tan head.  The aroma is pleasant - a perfect amount of malty goodness mixed with some light musk.  Lively carbonation which creates a smooth foamy feel going through the mouth.  This would be a perfect beer to drink with pizza.  It has a light cola aftertaste.
Bottle Pours out a brown with a little red. A great aroma of nuts and malt. Tast more of the nuts nice roast malt. This is another good brew from the classic Anchor. Thanks Pink

Aroma is a roasted scent with tones that remind me of orange liquor.  Color is a dark amber with very good carbonation and a thick tight tan head.  Taste is clean and malty.  Starting with a medium body it goes down crisp letting it feel lighter then it is.  Finish is a roasted malt flavor back with a spicy hop flavor that come out with a mild citrus (orange) and vanilla taste.  In the after taste its clean with a mild bitterness.  This is a very good brew and is better then I was expecting it to be.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown with a tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, and slight raisin.  Taste is the same, with caramel and roasted malt up front.  Raisins and spice detectable in the aftertaste.  A very enjoyable brew, and one I would definitely have again.
Pours a dark brown with a tannish head. good flavor, I can taste some raison with a decent amount of spice. One of the best bocks I have had. I would buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Dark brown with small tan head.  Smelled interesting, fruity, malty.  Flavor had a strange spice that made it a bit sour almost? Pretty good though.

12 oz. bottle - dark brown with ruby highlights; head formed just around the edges; aromas of oranges, dates and malts; medium body becoming increasingly creamy; fruits and a little spice in the flavors; im really getting to like this style; easy to drink and very good

Bottle. I was a little disappointed with this one. Oh, I thought it was good but I had higher expectations. Smell was a tad weaker then should be. Appearance was nice dark brown color. Flavor was good because I like dark beer but it was a little weak. Overall, good beer but if I had more options I would probably choose another.

Every time I here a reference to ths one its usually too late to buy a six-pack so I was in luck when I ran into some over at Ledgers Liquors, in Berkeley. Pours a small tan head with small bubbles, that disipates in only a few minutes. Nice dark brown color. To me a clear aroma of what must be chocolate malt. Taste is like a bock with dark malts in it. Perhaps a little more hoppy than a traditional bock. I like having a bock every once in a while, Im just not 100% sold on this one now that Ive tried it. May just have to do some additional studies" of teh style to be sure!!!

Pours a nice dark black, with a one-finger tan head.  Aroma is odd...light, but slightly musty, kinda like a grandmas basement.  Flavor is heavy on the malt, with hints of dried fruits, smoked wood, and roasted nuts.  Palate is thinner than expected, and finishes a bit too dry for my tastes.
Pours a very dark caramel, mild aroma.  Slightly smoky malty flavor, with a dry finish.  A decent bock from Anchor.
Smells a little hoppy yet malty with some candy.  Friendly goat chewing on a hop branch. Good clean malty impact for the palate. Aromatic and volatile. Alky finish is a hanger onner.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 3, 2008 Apparently this was recently distributed to NC for the first time. Dark fruits, roast, and some hops..  about what I expected.

looking forward to this one, but was disappointed. Toastyness was not evident at all in the nose or in the flavor. Dark fruits dominate. And then something sour showed up in the finish. Not desirable.

Blah. Aroma was weak. Could pick up some dark fruit in the distance. Pour was a nice deep dark amber with a thin tan ring for a head. The taste was so so. Strong vinous flavor of dark fruit and sticky sweet roasted malt. Heavy carbonation with a semi bitter aftertaste. Just average.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: (bottle): Pours a dark dark brown body, Big foamy off-tan head, good lacing, somewhat lasting. Very fresh aroma, outdoorsy, somewhat dusty. Malty, somewhat dusty, somewhat nutty taste. Good body, somewhat light. Spring-y. More creamy, fruity as it warms up.

Clear garnet color with a nice tan head. Aroma is first a whiff of hops then a more typical toffee malty smell. medium body and smooth. Decent taste is of mildly sweet malts and molasses flavored bread. Very easy drinking.  3237

text: This is a great looking drink - Smooth and sweet with a dry, moderate bitter finish. Very thin and somewhat tart. Bitter chocolate on the finish. Funny that Rob and I picked this up at 99Bottles  and rated it so closely. Good times.

pourchased at 99 bottles in federal way, washington.
pour is a dark brown with a red tint, large biege fluffy head, good lacing.
smell of cocoa, caramel, vanilla, fruit.
taste is tangy, carbonation throughout, tart fruit, malt, burnt caramel, end is dry and bitter.

Bottle. Pours a black colour with a tan head. On the nose I got liquorice, some chocolate and roasted malts. Promising! Too thin-bodied with some sweetness. Liquorice, molasses and roasted malts. I found the finish to be a bit weak

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 Provided by ilovedarkbeer at his latest tasting. Aroma is very heavy on coffee malts with a bit of clove and maybe even some menthol (and a bit of metal). Creamy, light brown head with good lacing. Nearly black in color. Taste is watery upfront with a salty, coffee, malty finish. Some alcohol.

Nose is nice roasted coffe and I think I detect some sort of minty note. Pours a black brown color with a decent sized tan head. Tastes like caramel, coffee, and finishes with a bit of semi sweet chocolate. Not amazing but my first dunkler bock, and I have to say I did enjoy it.

Bottle.  Pour is a thin, yet dark and leathery brown with a massive three or four finger tan head.  As the head dies back Im treated to some dark grain aromas with a touch of sweetness and some chocolate.  Flavor is a bit off... maybe I got a bad bottle, but I picked up a small touch of sourness that mixes with the chocolate/toffee and roastiness.

text: Draught at Waterfront.  Dark mahogany with a thin frothy cream colored head.  Aroma and flavor of brown sugar and grainy malts, with a layer of butterscotch.  Nice touch of roastiness therein and not overly sweet.  OK.
Quite delicious. Its got a medium bodied flavor of malt and low amount of hops. Its characters feels like a true German Bock, Kudos!!
The aroma is like cola, malt, yeast, and leaves. The appearance is dark brown with an average head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall its pretty good beer.

almost black pour with a thin caramel colored head.  malts on the nose along with caramel and brown sugar.   a little watery on the palate but a great taste and easy drinkability.

July 2006 - Beer poured really dark and huge head which left as quickly as it came.  Deep chocolate and cherry flavor with some nut.  Somewhat viney tasting and sweet caramel with sour finish...not crazy about this beer for some reason.
Pours dark brown, with a light brown head. Aroma is malt, caramel, and raisins. Flavor is roasted malt, caramel, hops, and toffee. Medium body. Decednt brew.

Bottle. Pours deep mahogany with a thick tan head. Malty nose with notes of caramel, straw and fudge. Medium body. Taste has noted of roasted malt, caramel and chestnut. Very good overall, I really enjoyed drinking it.

Sampled at Anchor, San Fran - June 2007. Clear dark brown (mahogany up to light) with a thick beige head. Raisins, carmelized sugars in the nose. Flavor of dark fruits, burnt raisin, dark caramel, toffee, a hint of roast, noble hops, a light alcohol kick and some lingering bitterness. Medium bodied with lively carbonation.

Dark color with pleasing carbonation and a rocky mocha head. Aroma of caramel with notes of cardboard. Started off with a very chilled sample, yet lovely carmel flavorings still leaked out. Crisp caramel throughout the session with a burnt finish and balanced sweetness. One of the better Anchor brews.

Nice oily brown pour like molasses with a foamy/creamy light brown head.  Roasted malt aroma with some sweet sugary bourbon and a touch of caramel.  The taste is smoked caramel and milk chocolate with some cocoa as well.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with a tan head that settles quickly.  Aroma is nice and features toasted nut, cocoa, chocolate, and tart berry (cant tell which one though).  Taste turns immediately to dark chocolate, then a slight cola flavor.  This flavor then gives way to the tart berry I picked up in the aroma, and yields to a nice light roast/hop bitter finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  This is a pretty good sessionable beer, and has a decent amount of complexity.
Surprisingly light body.  Tastes of caramel and roasted malt.  Sweet but cloying.

Dark and brown in color with reddish edges and a creamy head.  Aromas are a bit sugary with cherry and roasted grains.  Smooth texture, hopcit on the finish.  Nice amount of carbonation.  Tastes overwhelmingly of whole-grain toast.  Some coffee.  Rather plain.  Lots of breakfast notes in here.
Mild yeast aroma. Dark amber color with a medium brown head. Mostly sweet taste with a slight amount of bitterness in the finish that fades quickly. Slightly creamy palate.

12oz bottle. Sweet malty aroma. Not cloying. Some toasted caramel and toasted rye bread. Pours a nearly opaque brown/amber with a very thick and lasting khaki head. Bread dough, earthy malt, some slight grape and wood tannin on the tongue. Mild liquorice. Hints of wood and smoke. Medium bodied with a roasty dry finish.

12 oz bottle. Dark reddish brown color with small tan head. Very malty and vinous aroma with also sweetish, caramelly, toffeish and slightly nutty notes. Malty and vinous flavor with soft roast, chocolate, licorice, coffee as well as some woody and berryish notes.Tasty and complex brew!
Very nice dark mahogany with large foamy tan head.  Buttery chocolate aroma.  Great roasted buttery chocolate malts with a dry coffee finish.  Body is a tad watery, not very full, but easy drinking.

Aroma: at first smell there is light with caramel but as it gets to room temp the aroma fades to chocolate.
Thin head, deep red/dark brown appearance.
Taste: slight coffee upfront with a smoked finish.
Thin body.

Draught. Very smoky aroma with hints of butterscotch, coffee, and caramel. Dark brown, nearly black with a patchy but elegant head. Smooth palate with a strong smoke flavor, lightly sweet. A touch thin but immensely smooth.

Pours a deep ruby brown into the glass with minimal head. Aroma is sweet with some fruity notes.  Flavor is smooth and refreshing.  Theres some taste of burnt sugar and roasted grain.  The hops are present just enough to balance out the sweet profile of this beer.

An interesting brew, insofar as it challenges the styles boundaries to a huge degree. Very dark, almost opaque, with ruby highlights. One-finger, tan head. Aroma of strawberries & lemon.  Flavor is much less sweet than most dark bocks. In fact, sweetness plays a marginal role in the set of flavors. Sour cherry, chocolate, burned toast, and citric hops are the main flavors, with a touch of dark toffee in the first third.  The acidic quality does not feel like a bock, nor does the porter-like espresso bean roast.  If you like porters, you will probably particularly enjoy this.
Bottle.  Poured deep brown with thick tan head.  Aroma of swet malt and chocolate.  Medium body.  Bittersweet chocolate and malt, a bit of roast.  Toasty finish.  Worth drinking when you find it.

text: Beautiful dark beer, bottle poured with thick, creamy brown head. Smooth + Tasty. Slight hop linger with minimal hop presence. Chocolate and cherries, what a delicious beer.

I remember this beer differently, did they change the recipe? Now pours very dark brown, almost black, tall khaki head. Big meaty aroma, burnt chocolate, burnt wood, tastes like that old tale of "scaping the bottom of the kettles". Big flavor, earthy and hearty.

Pours a very dark ruby color, slightly opaque, with a small off-white head.  Aroma is of caramel, slightly toasted, and nutty.  The flavor is toasty, of chocolate, caramel, nuts, and coffee.  The mouth feel is a little thin for my liking... especially in such a malty beer.  Overall, quite good... I personally like it better than the Steam... sorry.

12 oz. bottle.
Pours very smoothly and flowing. A dark brown beer, with good moderately lasting tan head. Has a pleasant, sugary, malt aroma. Its got the best malt taste of any malty beer ive ever had.

12 oz. glass bottle- color of deep brown, with nice tan a head - nose of sweet malt, coco, and some dark fruit   taste of cappuccino, and malt simple but good- body is medium, dry and with medium carbonation  aftertaste of cappuccino, and dark milk chocolate

Poured from the familiar squat 12 oz bottle, this smooth, sweet elixer is an exceptional dark bock that, again, is undeserving of its 84 percentile rating on this site.
I believe it loses points because it has a low hops presense.
Read the definition of what a Dunkler Bock is supposed to be!
sweet, malty, nutty, and low carbination allow this to be an extremely quaffable beer!

Bottle.  Lives up to its name in appearance and aroma.  Dark, without much of a head.  Malty, almost molasses, aroma, without much evident hops.   Thick, with a caramel, molasses flavor that almost sticks to the tongue.  Too sweet.

text: Bottle 35,5 cl. Pours almost black with a yellowish tan head and a weak aroma of smoke and caramel. Aroma is a bit sweet with lots of roasted malts and caramel. Tastes more like a Porter than a Dunkler Bock. Finish is really short, both hoppy and metallic, unfortunately I didnt like this one that much

I opened this when I thought New England was finally going to lose a game last night.  But they pulled it out again.  I had cellared this one since spring and I think it helped mellow the beer.  Pours dark black/brown with a frothy tan head. It has  a sweet malty aroma and flavor.  Palate is medium/light, a bit of sharp carbonation, and lightly sweet. Fairly balanced light flavor with a mild bitter hops bite at the end..

caramel color with a small tan head. nut brittle aroma: toffee and nuts with some dark fruits. creamy, smooth, and thick body. toffee malt flavor with a light floral hop note, nuts, and prunes. very well balanced and just overall great

12oz. bottle. Pours a dark copper color with a thin tan head that laces well. Aroma is of sweet fruit and roasted malts. Flavor is of raisins, roasted malts and hint of cinnamon. Mouthfeel is smooth and velvet-like. A very good purchase.

Creamy medium lasting light brown head. Dark brown, almost black colour. Aroma is malty with roasty, coffe and nuts notes. Flavor is malty too with a strong roasty accent and a chocolate beginning then candy tones, ending in a initially malty (dark fruits) and then balanced, slightly roasty finish. Light to medium bodied.
dark brown with a thick burgundy head, it has coffee aroma with notes of molasses and prune.  full bodied, the flavor is roasty and chocolatey.
Dark brown colour, tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, caramel, dark fruits. Agree on the marshmellow citing. Flavour is of roasted malts and bitter coffee, and dark fruits. Bitter / dry finish.

This beer had that weird marshmellowy aroma and taste that I have found in a few beers during my beer drinking adventures.  Another one that had it that stands out the most is alesmiths ipa.  Anyways pour was a dark brown almost black color with huge foamy off white head.  Aroma was great, caramel, malts, dark fruits, raisins, big roastiness.  Flavor was similar but the marshmellow thing was too potent, as Ive stated before its not a bad trait, just weird for a beer.   The caramel flavor mixed extremely well with the figgy raisin taste.

From the cryptic bottling code on back, I believe this was packaged in December, 2006.  Pours a deep black with a solid, one-finger tan head.  Caramel and raisins, sweet chocolate and plums rise from the tulip.  Very nice and complex aroma for a fairly small beer.  The body is medium with chewy carbonation.  It explodes with bittersweet chocolate, fudge, raisans, bourbony plums, chocolate-covered cherries, the list goes on.  This one really surprised me.  Great stuff.
Bottle at "Stockholm Beer & Whiskey Festival 2007". Black - light brown head. Burned, sweetness, raisins, plums, light honey, nutty. Sharp/dry/burned finish.

Bottle, courtesy of kmweaver, poured into a dimpled mug. Pours a deep burgundy brown (garnet when held to the light) with a creamy, pitted, tan head that slowly diminishes. The aroma is of Raisinets, light malted milk, Root Beer Barrels (the hard candy). and a faint, fruity hop note. Medium-bodied and slick with a soft mouthfeel that quickly asserts its carbonation upon swallowing, wrapping your tongue in a cascade of tiny bubbles. The finish is quick with just a hint of hop bitterness and metal coming through. The flavor is surprisingly more complex than the nose. Sweet chocolate notes precede peat, weak coffee and dark fruit notes followed by a hint of the hops and metal mentioned above. This is my first beer of this style, and it wont be my last. Unfortunately, this is the one offering from Anchor that cannot be acquired locally. Much thanks again, Ken.

Huge dark yellow-cream head, totally stable, over ruby-shot, near black-beer. Very nicely hopped, with a background smell of caramel syrup. Bitter tinted cake-like sweet beer, very un-Bock-like hops, tannines, chocolate in the finish. Very full-bodied, chewy, warming. Very nice American Strong ale. A Bock? And 5.5% ???? - cant believe it.

Bottle.  Bottled on:  03/19/07.  A deep mahogany pour with a thick and fluffy light-mocha head that leaves rings of lace.  A nutty, malty aroma that features some chocolate and hints of rye bread.  Medium-bodied.  Starts with a good deal of caramel malts and Red Delicious apples.  Finishes toasty with some cocoa and raisins.  Not too shabby.
Dark brown color with attractive garnet highlights.  Strong malty aroma and lightly toasted flavor of sweet malt.  The medium body beer lingers with some alcohol warmth.

Roasted overall flavors but very winelike actually, making it a bit too acidic for my liking. It also had a big apple-like aftertaste, which I did not like either. I havent tried many bock beers but I think I prefer other offerings from Anchor more.

Poured a very nice dark reddish brown (I almost thought I was pouring a sweet stout).  Head was soapy looking and aroma is a sweet roasted scent.  Flavor was also lightly sweet with a roasted coffee aftertaste.  Overall, very very nice, with elements of sweet stouts.  Definitely will require future purchases!

Bottle poured into a snifter.  Very deep brown with decent head.  Nutty roasted, almond-like aroma - more subtle than I hoped.  Highly carbonated and quite light weight on the palate - not rich or creamy.  No aftertaste.  Flavor is there but is very muted.  Essentially, this beer was not at all what I expected - but it wasnt bad.  Id have again.

Rich Chocolately deep brown, but basically black in the glass with mild light tan head.  Fairly light smell but it is a roasty, malty smell with chocolately, caramel hints.  Rich and carbonated body, with mild sweetness, a slight hint of bitterness and a nice bitter-sweet mild coffee like finish.  A touch bland, but my bottle might be quite old.  One Id love to have fresh.  Still good nonethess and not a disappointment at all.
12 oz bottle,pours dark brown,tan head,malty nose,light carb,sweet malty litte bitterness,ok but nothing great.
