Nothing distinctive in the flavor but smooth and refreshing.   Delecious, refreshing, not overpowering, recommed it and would have again.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: 12oz. bottle.  Dark red with orange with a small creamy light brown head.  Caramel, molasses, raisins, and some earthen hops in the aroma.  Caramel, oily nuttiness in the flavor.  Some hop resinous character in the finish with residual sweetness.  Mouthfeel is medium heavy, somewhat sticky.

Dark brown, brown foam as well, bigger bubbles like ale not lager. Slightly dirty molasses like aroma with some piney hops underneath, a little wiff of rotten egg sulphur in there too. Tastes like a wet dog, some sulphur and cradboard, but with fairly pleasant piney and resinous hop burps. Not nearly enough clean bread-like malt, not at all like a good bock as I understand it, no way you can even compare it, and really not a beer that I enjoy.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with Sammy and DrJay, my bottle.  Poured deep bright refractive mahogany with a yellowish solid, lasting, foamy head.  Aroma was initially very strong for a bock, waves of fresh resiny/oily hops, deep sweet roast malt, yeast - it settled down to a pleasant, less aggressive nose after a bit.  The flavour was more what I would expect from a bock - slightly leafy roast caramel malt, with the hops emerging in a moderately long, somewhat appleseed bitter finish.  Mouthfeel was astringent, syrupy, average body, not much carbonation - on balance an excellent bock!

Mahogony colour with mocha head, lots of lace. Molasses and chocolate malt aroma. Creamy and tongue tingle. Molasses and roast coffee aftertaste with coffee oil slickness. Bittersweet. Medium-full mouthfeel. It all works together, and would have again

What an amazing bock this turned out to be. Aroma is a sweet and roasty smell of dark malt and fresh wild flower type of hops. Color is a dark brown with a sand colored head. The flavor is mild and light with a faint background of caramel and lightly roasted malt. Has a notice of hop in the flavor as well but not as apparent as in the aroma. Another great offering from Anchor and it makes me happy they finally decided to sell it outside the SF bay area.

Bottled.  Dark brown pour with a walnutty stained look.  Light, creamy head of gentle beige.  Rich aroma of chocolate licorice and mild coffee with a little maltiness as well.  Texture is rather thin, but has a pleasing prune tone to it.  Tons of chocolate licorice is the standout overpowering trait of this brew.  Overall a clean and well-balanced beer thats a touch on the thin side.

Bottle sampled at OBriens: Mahogany color, nose of toast, grapefruit and caramel, old pop tarts. Lots of sweet, chalky and unexpectantly strong salty malt. The finish is very nice and balanced. Decent, good bock.

22 oz. bottle from BevMo, Walnut Creek.  Pours dark ruddy brown with a small beigey head.  Aroma of dark ripe fruits, coffee, molasses and herby hops.  Rich roasty malt flavors, bittering spices, astringent coffee, herbal hops and a touch of pepper in the finish.  Medium body, creamy carbonation.  Nice bock.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2006 Very dark brown with a red glare. On top sits a medium-sized creamy, beige head. Rich, sweet chocolate aroma with some vanilla notes, more like an imperial stout than a stout. Liquorice as well. Flavours are still sweet with chocolate and liquorice, but the roasted flavours are more pronounced, leading up to a dry finish. Also some fruits in the background. Soft on the palate, medium-bodied. Strangely, the ABV is not stated on the label, but the brewerys web site states 5.5%. All in all, a delicious, though slightly light-weight imperial stout.

Very dark Bock. Darker than most Dopplebocks. Thin brown head. Rich, full aroma, malty and complex, slightly vinous with cocoa, vanilla, leather. Full bodied.  Dusty roasted flavor with some plum and piney hops finishing bitter and slightly sweet. Reminds me of an unspiced OSA and is not like any bock Ive had. Good though.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2012 Loved this one the first time I had it (4.3) and really thought the malt character was outstanding.  Six years later, how does it stack up?  Dark brown with a thin head.  There are some rich caramel notes in the aroma with a light toastiness.  The malts are toasty first with light caramels.  Unfortunately, the malts thin out in the finish.  Not nearly as good as I had it before.

Thanks to Enniskillen for providing this one at the tasting!  Pours brown with a thin head and clinging lace.  Aroma has a floral sweetness with a touch of plum.  Flavor is smoky sweet with some sour strawberry.  Palate is a bit thin.  Reminds me of the Anchor  Christmas 05 offering, but better.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: An obscure beer along the same lines as the Porter in some of its qualities. In fact a mix of the two may be a good call to harness the better qualities of both. I honestly liked this one. What it lacked in complexity, it made up for in a relentless onslaught on my tastebuds, and I notice Im not the only one to wonder what the bloody ABV is?!! (In a way its good not to know as generally higher ABV beers rate better, so this is merely up to the beers profile!). Poured into a chalice, cool but not cold. Looked outstanding in the glass; deep set ruby body, good clarity, with a thick, creamy beige crown that managed a good trail of thinning lace. Dusty cocoa, aniseed and tart, red fruits in the aroma with a hint of burnt sugar and bitter herbs giving it a little depth. Similar in the mouth with more dark fruits and a strong showing of black patent style charred wood malts. Soft on the tongue; not overly big in the body department but smooth in feel and well rounded in flavour. Cocoa takes a back seat as notes of blackcurrents, raisins and some burnt fruit sugars take hold, giving it a gentle astringency and a bitter edge just prior to the swallow before a deep, drying malt and hops finish. Lingering for a good hour afterwards with smoke and raisins filling the mouth like a burnt Christmas fruit cake, this was quite a different take on the old word Bock. One Im going to try and grab again as long as its available with a little more ease than the round trip from the U.S. to Amsterdam and then onto Perth, Australia. Enjoyable!!! (1 pint/ 6 fl. Oz, Stamped 5YN, Intl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)

Bottled.  Near black, minimal head. The aroma holds coffee, lactic acid and berries. Surprisingly light bodied with hard crystal malt  character. Notes of papery malt and chocolate. Fairly low bitterness. Theres lots of good stuff in here, but a bock needs a big, soft maltiness - not hard, sharp crystal malt.

Sampled at Dickinsonbeers NJ January gathering.  from Mike/EyeDrinkAle?  thanks for this treat, whoever it was.  cloudy dark brown color, foamy tan head.  slightly acidic and sour hoppy aroma.  flavor is dry malt and a little smoky/tart for a bock.  dryish roasty finish.

This beer has a dark brown body - hue apperance and a coarse light brown scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the bottle and it had no carbonic acid. The initial flavor taste is very bitter with a light caramel afther tast.

Bottle left at Dickinsonbeers by EDA. 
Light brown color with some red highlights and a small tan head. Mild roasted malt aroma with some brown sugar and chocolate. Flavor of chocolate malt, dark, dried fruits and bittersweet chocolate.
Poured dark brown with a light tan head.  Aroma of molasses and sweet fruit.  Taste is sweet and vinous with hints of chocolate and cinnamon.  Finish is dry and yeasty.

Well, the availability is a bit broader than as described. Here I am in Perth and the best grog shop in the country sold this one to me. Thanks IBS. Hey, I just had a look at the last rating (gidday Bob, here we are rating the same bloody beer in the same bloody city and we have never met, welcome back) and was about to moan about the lack of ABV details. The nose is good if not a bit of dried fruitiness with some harsh maltiness. Flavour is potentially fine but there is a degree of wheatiness that detracts from the body as well as contributing an unfavourable harshness in mouthfeel and flavour. Too thin overall (would like to comment in the context of the ABV) and somewhat lacking in all thos factors that make a beer great.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text:
Interesting to note that the commercial description says it is supposedly available "only in the SFB area" yet one can purchase it halfway around the the globe. Also bottle lists no ABV. Opaque ruby brown with a lfine bubbled tan head. Grainy malt, molasses, cough mixture and dried fruit aroma. Medium chewy relatively low carb palate.
MIldly sweet caramel burnt toffee medium bitter roasted malt and herbal hoppy flavours. Nutty dry finish. I agree with Gary - it does remind me of their porter.

Quite dark in body with ruby tinges and a medium size, light tan head. Toasted malt aroma that got better as it warmed. Dried fruit in the taste, rich, dry, liquorice and meaty with a light bitter finish. Quite like this drop although I probably couldnt drink too many at once. Reminds me a bit of there porter as well. A fairly dry bock.

Pours dark and coppery, boardering on full brown, but a shade or two lighter.  Smells of rotting fruit, raisins and caramel.  Taste is of overripe fruit, slightly nutty and bitter dark chocolate. Mouthfeel is thick and the finish is slightly bitter and lingering,
Very nice dark coloured bock. Nice sweet, malty and bitter taste. Overall a very nice bock, one of the best Ive had.

Dark color, medium creamy brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, licorice and chocolate, but overwhelmed also by strong hops, which give the aroma a specific character. Creamy texture, smooth taste. Slightly sourish, initially sweet chocolat and malty taste. Towards the end it becomes very bitter. I guess this is a typical American Bock: bigger, stronger, but also better than the classic bocks? Good stuff.

Thanks M500 for the sample: Looks the part with a deep coppery hue, good head and lace. Toffee and caramel balanced with some nice fruity undertones. A bit smoky and some bitterness as well. Yummy! Sticky but thin-bodied. I sure would like to try it again.

anchor tour 2k5 bitchez:
thick creamy cappuccino head. dark red brown body. hoppy chocolate gin and alc. on aroma. chocoloate dark rye flavor with a bit of bread. i was too drunk at the time to give this a palate rating, so im guessing. ehhe.

Not bad, in that there is character here, but it wasnt really to my preferences.  Aroma of grape, cola, body odor, mustiness, and alcohol.  Pretty strong bitterness following roasted and chocolate flavor notes.  Thanks Jazz88.
sticky aftertaste. Quite heavy for a spring bock. Otherwise a rather pleasant beer for a lazy saturday afternoon.

Nearly clear, caramel-y color, thick, lush, pinkish, cocoa-toned foam.

Sweetness in the nose, roasty-toasty, toffee-ish, very pleasant.

Malty attack on the tongue, and wonderfully mellow. A bit grainy and gritty, but still fruity and flush with flavor. Rich, dark, tasty. Chocolate malts? Very solid.

Warm and comforting in the mouth, easily drinkable, tenaciously tasty...I like it, I like it...Good roast for a bock. Id like to have this again, and again...very smooth, and luscious on the palate, an expertly brewed bock.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a minimal head. Smells of roasty malt and chocolate. Tastes like dark chocolate, coffee, and malts. Bitter on the finish. Medium body, not overly sweet. Quite enjoyable.
nice dry bock beer, tastes like grapefruit , roasted malt and sweet. drinkable.
On draught. Tasted during trip to California. Red dark brown colour very nice smooth and creamy head. Nice aroma of sweetness, caramel and chocolate. Great taste of burned malt and chocolate.

Sampled out of the bottle, thanks to John. Pours a dark brown color, small off white head. Aroma is toffee, burn malt, lots of sweetness. Flavor is dominated by malt, chocolate, caramel, nuts. Dry finish

bomber bottle. pours a deep brown wtih hints of red and a decent beige head.  Mocha aromas. Flavors of raisins, coffee, and smoky malt. Finishes a little dry and bitter.  A little bit light bodied for a bock, but very drinkable.

compliments of Mrdick.  Pretty good stuff huge head redish colour.  IS kinda creamy
bitter/dry aftertaste.

A big thanks to beerguy101 for hooking me up with this beer. It pours a deep brown color with very evident reds available under flourescent light. The head was tanned and soapy with very nice lacing. The aroma was vanilla, coffee, mocha, cocoa, marshmellows and brown sugar...very sweet and stout/bockish. Flavor-wise its full bodied and tastes just like a tootsie roll. A dry bittersweet chocolate flavor followed by a balanced hoppy citrus attack. Vanilla, caramel, cocoa, chocolate, wood and brown sugar balance the palate into a dry grainy finish. Very active carbonation, slightly bready in its finish. Roasted barley front and smore-like mid-sip. Interesting and sweet.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2005 Bottled. Roasted and black currant aroma. Very dark brown color, light brown almost creamy head, very nice lace. Pretty bitter, roasted, blackcurrant, coffee. Medium body and dry but thin finish. Judging it as it is then its a fine brew. Judging it as a bock it fails in many ways - not sweet enough, too bitter, no butterscotch, totally wrong choice of hops.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2006 Rerate 4/11/06, aged for roughly a year: Pours a transparent dark mahogany with a large, frothy tan head.  Aroma has changed a lot, resembling more of a doppelbock, and bery authentic with some sweet earthy caramel malt and milk chocolate notes.  Starts with a nice slightly aged caramel malty sweetness with a touch of hoppy bitterness.  Finishes smooth, but somewhat thin.  Still, a very nice bock.

Originally rated on 9/11/05: Lightly transparent dark amber brown pour with a lightly-lacing, frothy off-white head.  Aroma has some earthy milk chocolate and lots of piney hops, that although they make it deviate from the style, add a good amount of balance.  Body starts with a creamy lactose sweetness, some earthy caramel and fresh piney hop flavor.  Seems like a lighter recipe of Old Foghorn.  Very drinkable and flavorful, just not too true to style.

Bottle bought in the Mitra drinks shop, a  90 seconds walk from the place where I spend my working hours. Dark brown color. Lasting creamy head. Coffee, caramel and chocolate in the aroma. Malty flavor with chocolate, blackcurrant (Cascade hops?), roasted malt, grapes and laurel. Hints of coffee. Medium bodied. Not a bock beer like German or Dutch bocks Ive tasted. Nevertheless a fine and tasty beer.

many thanks goes to enniskillen for the hookup.this bock pours a deep dark brown with a nice creamy head that fades quickly.as the head sits it leaves tiny webbing.the aroma was a nice blend of chcoolate malts and piney hops.the flavor was much of the same with a bit of a tang finish.nice stuff.

Lightly sweaty, dry, bready, pumpernickel and rye aroma.  Clear chestnut brown body with ruby highlights and low tan head that recedes to partial cover.  Bready rye-like character with plenty of raisins and floral tones.  Medium-light body with fair effervescence.  Bottle enjoyed with muzzlehatch, Olivier_MTL and Rastacouere.
Dark mahoganey body, creamy tan head. Aroma has chocolate, wet dog, and vanilla tobacco. Slight spice and chocolate in taste, with some tree rook. Some smoked vanilla tobacco as well... Pretty good!

Chocolate, nutty and roasted malt aroma. A deep reddish brown with a humongous two finger thick tan head. Some fruity sweetness in the fore..starts out with raisin and cherries and ends with a bit of chocolate covered cherry sweetness. Very big malt profile. Very pleasant aftertase. A touch of smokiness in the far aftertase. A very good looking beer I have to say. The head is creamy and firm which just invites you to take a sip.

Bottle. Mahogony color with a nice beige head. Caramel aroma with some fruitiness and light roastiness. Lighter bodied than expected, but makes it more drinkable. Roasty flavor with some background chocolate and dark fruit. Nice lingering coffee flavors.
Densely clouded reddish brown, thick head formation. Dark fruit, burnt raisin bread aroma. Vary sweet malt palate, caramel, toffee with fruitcake, burnt raisins, some choclate.

Couleur brune aux reflets rougeâtres parsemés dune dense mousse beige.  Arômes propres au style, caramel, toffee, grains, foin, grange et herbes.  Légèrement sucré en bouche, malt rôti et aux réminiscences de noix grillées sur une touche de caramel.  Corps dépaisseur semi mince à moyenne,  faible carbonatation, finale sèche nous quittant sur une note damertume prononcée.  Merci Barry!

I have had this a few times, about time I got around to rating. The head is slightly yellowish and tops a dark brown body that has some orange highlights. The aroma is sweet donuts with bananas and pears. The taste is roasted and clean with black walnut shells. It also has a hint of molasses or maple. A decent bock, but I expected a little more from Anchor.

Pours to a medium beige head that thins out to a whispy swirl.  Spotty lacing.  The body is mahogany.  The aroma is very strong.  A touch hot.  Bocky.  The flavor is burnt chocolate and overly roasted malts.  Thanks John, but I cant say I liked this...

Big thanks to JPDIPSO for sharing this one!  Deep chestnut in color, translucent when put to light, and a dark creamy tan rung along the edges.  Rich dark chocolate powder and caramel throughout the aroma, accentuated by pecans and walnuts.  Glides across the palate, drawing out brazed walnuts, chocolate and rye.  Rich semi-sweet chocolate morsels and a little hint of smoke.  Dactylically speaking, its a conundrum, but the flavor is solid.  Toffee, Rolo like finish.

Very dark color w/ a nice tan head and some good lacing.  Smells of big sweet malt nice hop and plums w/ brown sugar.  Palate is full and creamy yet ligh.  Flavor is light carmel malt and not much else.  I was dissapointed in the taste after the way it smelled.
Thanks to John for sharing.

Bottle.  Though I had this at Noogfest, I was so palate fatigued (ok ok drunk) at the point I tried it, I have no idea what my notes on it meant.  Fortunately for me, goldtwins came through with another tasting for me.  Dark brown pour.  Rich strongly hopped aroma, woody to me and loads of caramel.  More rich caramel flavors and woody hops and roasted grains.  Light bitter finish.
Poured a very dark brown with a slight reddish tint.  Aroma of dark fruits and chocolate with undertones of hops.  Roasty flavors with some light chocolate.  Semi-dry with a mild bitter finish.

Bottle provided by Pailhead.  Brown colored with a ruby hue when backlit.  Roasted grain, coffee, a bit of soy and smoke as it warms.  Medium bodied.  Lots of roasted grain in flavor.  Fair hop backing.  Fair.

Clear mahogany, big fluffy light brown head. Fruity, almost leathery nose proposes gentle earthy hints and richer brown sugar and toffee darker malt character. Juicy and grapey at the same time, this is a multi-faceted bock, fairly spicy. The palate did not quite hold up for me, the finish being a bit bland. Nevertheless, the nice coffee-roasty- nutty and dry interplays are pleasant to feel. The body proposes ample maltiness, a fitting light-medium carbonation to cut through the medium airy body. Did not seem to interest me as much as my buddies, but definitely good.

¿Bock? What is this thing bock? From what I can tell its a good beer and as per their own description and the way things have gone in general what defines a bock beer has been blurred to a great extent. Had the thought of this being like their porter placed in my brain and that became hard to escape. But I would say for good reason. A bit sweeter than the porter I believe. An excellent beer by any measure. Many thanks to Rich (MrDick)

22 ounce bottle sampled with tiggmtl, Rastacouere and Olivier_MTL at Ashleys in Ann Arbor MI.  Bottle acquired in trade with Irishsnake, thanks so much!  Reddish-dried blood-brown body, creamy lasting small off-white head with just a touch of lacing...herb-infused caramel aroma, woody character and bready yeast appears with time...body is also herbal in character, quite dry for a bock, though thick caramel malts are always present along with bakers chocolate, rye, and I think some aloe...like a bock overlaid with typical Anchor spicy herbal qualities (e.g. OSA, Porter)...probably far from perfect stylistically, but certainly one of the most interesting bocks Ive had lately and more proof if we needed it that the old guys like Anchor and SN can still keep up with the young turks.  Bravo.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2010 Courtesy of Pailhead. Dark brown, nice beige head, clings slightly. Aroma is very toasty, slightly bready/doughy, not much else. Flavor is a bit understated. Again tiny bit of toasted grain, slight roasted character and not much else. Very clean, but just not enough going on.

Chestnut colors with a hint of rudy when held to the light. Two fingers worth of tan foam that is quite lasting. The aroma leads to an impression of a highly malty brew. Sorghum and brown sugar mix with toasted vanilla wafers and roasted nuts. Lightly roasted coffee beans coated in mild dark chocolate. Fairly dry, yet quite full bodied. Mild noble hops bitterness mixes well with a the toasty malt. While I can not say this is the best bock Ive ever had it is certainly a very fine beer. Long linger of malts on the tongue help you remember the malt joy a a good malty brew. I love a malty brew and the flavors continue to intensify as this one warms. They really need to make more of this.

Bottle discovered at Florians in Truckee, CA.  Thanks for having this!  Clear, but so dark that its opaque unless held up to light.  A unique magenta-red color in more standard indoor lighting.  Topped with a light brown head of creamy carbonation and medium-large in size, this baby can lace!  She does so in medium to thin sheets, completely coating the glass with a head that is fully lasting.  Aroma is yeasty sweet with roasted caramel, honey, fresh baked banana bread when you cut it open, dark fruits, chocolate and a hint of alcohol.  Body is medium with tons of soft, foamy carbonation giving it the allusion of a full body and leaving the mouth pleasantly dry.  Flavor is loaded with dark, roasted and burnt fruits.  Wow!  Malty, but not sweet.  Prune is big, with a tart plumb flavor and a finish of roasted, burned hazlenuts and fruit that is lightly bitter.  Rich chocolate undertones remind me of "Godiva Belgian Dark" ice cream.   Well balanced, complex.  Hopefully I can buy more on Tuesday.  Becomes noticably alcoholic as it warms, and somewhat harsh...I had anticipated improvement as it warmed--considering how dark it is--but I was wrong.  Similar to their porter and quite enjoyable.  Old Ale + Porter = Anchor Bock, eh?

Tap @ Toronado.  Dark brown to black color with a foamy brown head.  Solid malty (whoppers) flavors with some wafers and sweetness.  The aroma has a nice touch of fruit.  A dry finish with a long malty aftertaste.  Fairly nice full flavors.

Mahoghany with tan effervescent head. Aroma is deep and rich with caramel, banana bread, slight cinnamon and celery. Flavor includes milk chocolate, some hints of pumpernickel bread, and bitter-roasted coffee. Finishes rather dry with a surprising amount of bitterness. All in all, quite delicious.

Wonderful treat found outside San Francisco despite what the press release says.  Rich malty and sweet without being cloying.  Perfect balance of bitterness to accentuate the chocolate toasy malt flavors.  If you like malt, this is the beer for you.

Fruity aromatic notes of raisins and figs waft from my glass as I pour this beer.  Pours a deep, dark, amber color that shows ruby notes when held up to the light.  As well as the fruitiness I get notes of chocolate, a hint of lightly spicy hops, toasted malt.  This is really quite interesting in the nose, it is richly malty.  The taste is ever so lightly sweet, it is richly malty compared to the sweetness, which is quite nice.  The beer has notes of chocolate, toasted malt, and dark caramel.  This beer finishes quite dry, with a lightly astringent note of toasted malt that tends to linger a bit.  This note makes you thirsty and ready for another sip.  This beer has a fairly light body to it, at least for a bock, it does have a decent amount of mouthcoating maltiness to it though.  There is a bit of spiciness to this beer that I would attribute to hops, other than this the beer is pretty low on the hopping scale; there is just enough to make sure the malt is not cloying.  This is really quite nice, and is almost a quaffing bock, by which I mean a 22oz bottle is just about the right amount.

Bottled.  Pours a rich mahogany color with a frothy tan head.  Slight malt and roast aromas.  Toasty flavor, almost to the point of smoke.  Kindda a bitter chocolate thing going on as well.  Much milder flavor than I was expecting but very clean and quite well done.

Bottle:  Courtesy of beerguy101 via trade.  Roasted malt and roasted grain aroma with a touch of coffee.  Pours a dark brown with no transparency.  Off-white head that is short lasting.  Very roasty in malt and grain.  As it warms light chocolate and caramel make their way into the finish.  Very nice, but a somewhat weak aroma hurts the final score.

Wheaty sweet aroma with some maltiness.  Reddish brown in color with a nice thick head.  Nice balance of toasty and bready malts, slight chocolate and wheat, with a blend of hops.  A little sweetness like anchor steam.  Lingering hoppy burps.  Nice effort and very enjoyable.  Plus I love the bottle.  Thanks to Ernie, Flipbrewer, for the deliciousness.

Bottle: Deep ruby, hues of brown sugar, moderate to large foamy head, light beige in color, very sticky lacing. &nbsp Bready aroma, immature plums, and dark malts on the nose. &nbsp Quite malty, bready, and very tasty. &nbsp However, this screams to me that it wants to be a touch sweeter. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Heavy roast malt finish, bready, but not as viscous I would have thought. &nbsp Needs to be sweetened up a bit. &nbsp Kinda comes across as more of an Ale than a Lager, if that makes any sense. &nbsp I applaud Anchor for doing a new beer. &nbsp A few changes and I think it would be splendid! &nbsp Thanks a bunch Ernie!

22 oz bottle. Rich brown color with a medium sized head amd lots of lacing. Taste is smooth and light with some toastiness and caramel. Some roastiness and bittersweet chocolate. I like the idea of Anchor trying something new but Id like to see this just a bit hoppier.

Dark brown, moderate head. . Clean crisp aroma, with note od walnuts and a hint burnt toast. Nice flavors of malt, with a nutty, burnt toast note - in a very restrained way. Extremely smooth. Not oever the top, but extremely well made.

Thanks for sending this one Flipbrewer. It poured a dark black with a moderate tan head. The palate is a little thin but the flavor stands up with some roasted nuts, dark chocolate, and coffee. Not very much sweetness exists. Overall it was a good beer.

22 oz bottle. Dark red color. Large sized beige foamy head, long lasting lacing. Aroma is fruity and sweet, touch of chocolate and cherries. A medium bodied bock. Malts are chocolate, dark fruit and a little roasty. Hops are slightly bittering and a little spicy. The beer is a LOT drier and less sweet than I was expecting. It has a nice dry crisp finish. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is crisp and dry. Aftertaste is fruity and sweet.

beer pours a deep ruby red, with a tan head that retains well and laces nicely.  nose is very good, dominated by notes of bitter chocolate.  flavor is on the dry and roasty side for a bock - which I like, as it is not all malty/sticky.  some may find it a bit sharp.  it has a nice, drying mouthfeel and drinks easily.  nice effort, although some may expect a richer and maltier beer.
